    <title>A chromosome-based draft sequence of the hexaploid bread wheat (Triticum aestivum) genome | Science</title>

<meta name="DC.Title" content="A chromosome-based draft sequence of the hexaploid bread wheat (Triticum aestivum) genome" />
<meta name="DC.Identifier" content="10.1126/science.1251788" />
<meta name="DC.Date" content="2014-07-18" />
<meta name="DC.Publisher" content="American Association for the Advancement of Science" />
<meta name="DC.Rights" content="Copyright © 2014, American Association for the Advancement of Science" />
<meta name="DC.AccessRights" content="restricted" />
<meta name="DC.Relation" content="10.1126/science.1257983" />
<meta name="DC.Description" content="An ordered draft sequence of the 17-gigabase hexaploid bread wheat ( Triticum aestivum ) genome has been produced by sequencing isolated chromosome arms. We have annotated 124,201 gene loci distributed nearly evenly across the homeologous chromosomes and subgenomes. Comparative gene analysis of wheat subgenomes and extant diploid and tetraploid wheat relatives showed that high sequence similarity and structural conservation are retained, with limited gene loss, after polyploidization. However, across the genomes there was evidence of dynamic gene gain, loss, and duplication since the divergence of the wheat lineages. A high degree of transcriptional autonomy and no global dominance was found for the subgenomes. These insights into the genome biology of a polyploid crop provide a springboard for faster gene isolation, rapid genetic marker development, and precise breeding to meet the needs of increasing food demand worldwide." />
<meta name="DC.Contributor" content="The International Wheat Genome Sequencing Consortium (IWGSC)" />
<meta name="article:published_time" content="2014-07-18" />
<meta name="article:section" content="Research Article" />
<meta name="citation_title" content="A chromosome-based draft sequence of the hexaploid bread wheat (Triticum aestivum) genome" />
<meta name="citation_abstract" lang="en" content="&lt;p&gt;An ordered draft sequence of the 17-gigabase hexaploid bread wheat (&lt;i&gt;Triticum aestivum&lt;/i&gt;) genome has been produced by sequencing isolated chromosome arms. We have annotated 124,201 gene loci distributed nearly evenly across the homeologous chromosomes and subgenomes. Comparative gene analysis of wheat subgenomes and extant diploid and tetraploid wheat relatives showed that high sequence similarity and structural conservation are retained, with limited gene loss, after polyploidization. However, across the genomes there was evidence of dynamic gene gain, loss, and duplication since the divergence of the wheat lineages. A high degree of transcriptional autonomy and no global dominance was found for the subgenomes. These insights into the genome biology of a polyploid crop provide a springboard for faster gene isolation, rapid genetic marker development, and precise breeding to meet the needs of increasing food demand worldwide.&lt;/p&gt;" />

<meta name="citation_reference" content="citation_journal_title=Plant Breed.;citation_author=H. S. Randhawa;citation_title=Application of molecular markers to wheat breeding in Canada;citation_pages=458-471;citation_volume=132;citation_year=2013" />
<meta name="citation_reference" content="citation_journal_title=BMC Plant Biol.;citation_author=N. S. Harris;citation_author=G. J. Taylor;citation_title=Cadmium uptake and partitioning in durum wheat during grain filling;citation_pages=103;citation_volume=13;citation_year=2013;citation_pmid=23856013;citation_doi=10.1186/1471-2229-13-103" />
<meta name="twitter:title" content="A chromosome-based draft sequence of the hexaploid bread wheat (Triticum aestivum) genome" />
<meta name="twitter:card" content="summary_large_image" />
<meta name="twitter:image" content="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/345/6194/1251788/F1.large.jpg" />
<meta name="twitter:description" content="An ordered draft sequence of the 17-gigabase hexaploid bread wheat ( Triticum aestivum ) genome has been produced by sequencing isolated chromosome arms. We have annotated 124,201 gene loci distributed nearly evenly across the homeologous chromosomes and subgenomes. Comparative gene analysis of wheat subgenomes and extant diploid and tetraploid wheat relatives showed that high sequence similarity and structural conservation are retained, with limited gene loss, after polyploidization. However, across the genomes there was evidence of dynamic gene gain, loss, and duplication since the divergence of the wheat lineages. A high degree of transcriptional autonomy and no global dominance was found for the subgenomes. These insights into the genome biology of a polyploid crop provide a springboard for faster gene isolation, rapid genetic marker development, and precise breeding to meet the needs of increasing food demand worldwide." />
<meta name="og-title" property="og:title" content="A chromosome-based draft sequence of the hexaploid bread wheat (Triticum aestivum) genome" />
<meta name="og-url" property="og:url" content="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/345/6194/1251788" />
<meta name="og-site-name" property="og:site_name" content="Science" />
<meta name="og-description" property="og:description" content="An ordered draft sequence of the 17-gigabase hexaploid bread wheat ( Triticum aestivum ) genome has been produced by sequencing isolated chromosome arms. We have annotated 124,201 gene loci distributed nearly evenly across the homeologous chromosomes and subgenomes. Comparative gene analysis of wheat subgenomes and extant diploid and tetraploid wheat relatives showed that high sequence similarity and structural conservation are retained, with limited gene loss, after polyploidization. However, across the genomes there was evidence of dynamic gene gain, loss, and duplication since the divergence of the wheat lineages. A high degree of transcriptional autonomy and no global dominance was found for the subgenomes. These insights into the genome biology of a polyploid crop provide a springboard for faster gene isolation, rapid genetic marker development, and precise breeding to meet the needs of increasing food demand worldwide." />

/*! loadCSS rel=preload polyfill. [c]2017 Filament Group, Inc. MIT License */
!function(a){if(a.loadCSS){var b=loadCSS.relpreload={};if(b.support=function(){try{return a.document.createElement("link").relList.supports("preload")}catch(b){return!1}},b.poly=function(){for(var b=a.document.getElementsByTagName("link"),c=0;c<b.length;c++){var d=b[c];"preload"===d.rel&&"style"===d.getAttribute("as")&&(a.loadCSS(d.href,d,d.getAttribute("media")),d.rel=null)}},!b.support()){b.poly();var c=a.setInterval(b.poly,300);a.addEventListener&&a.addEventListener("load",function(){b.poly(),a.clearInterval(c)}),a.attachEvent&&a.attachEvent("onload",function(){a.clearInterval(c)})}}}(this);
    </script>
    <script id="loadcss">
      /*! CSS rel=preload polyfill. Depends on loadCSS function. [c]2016 @scottjehl, Filament Group, Inc. Licensed MIT  */
(function( w ){
  // rel=preload support test
  if( !w.loadCSS ){
    return;
  }
  var rp = loadCSS.relpreload = {};
  rp.support = function(){
    try {
      return w.document.createElement( "link" ).relList.supports( "preload" );
    } catch (e) {
      return false;
    }
  };

  // loop preload links and fetch using loadCSS
  rp.poly = function(){
    var links = w.document.getElementsByTagName( "link" );
    for( var i = 0; i < links.length; i++ ){
      var link = links[ i ];
      if( link.rel === "preload" && link.getAttribute( "as" ) === "style" ){
        w.loadCSS( link.href, link );
        link.rel = null;
      }
    }
  };

  // if link[rel=preload] is not supported, we must fetch the CSS manually using loadCSS
  if( !rp.support() ){
    rp.poly();
    var run = w.setInterval( rp.poly, 300 );
    if( w.addEventListener ){
      w.addEventListener( "load", function(){
        w.clearInterval( run );
      } );
    }
    if( w.attachEvent ){
      w.attachEvent( "onload", function(){
        w.clearInterval( run );
      } )
    }
  }
}( this ));
    </script>

6.85257177 62.2778949 4.48059833zM59.2561407 48.2324528C60.3070499 48.1007785 61.2268021 47.9689206 62.1465542 47.7053884 63.3289878 47.3099983 63.8545342 45.9921536 63.8545342 44.5426347L63.8545342 24.2479007C63.7231935 22.7983818 63.1976471 21.4805371 62.1465542 20.6899405 61.3581427 20.1628761 59.3874814 19.3720959 58.3362048 19.3720959L58.3362048 18.0542512 69.7670693 17.263471 70.1610914 17.7905354 70.1610914 44.1474282C70.1610914 45.5969472 70.8181622 46.7829339 71.869255 47.4418562 72.7890072 47.9689206 73.9714408 48.2324528 74.7596686 48.2324528L74.7596686 49.6821554 59.3872977     </div>

    <div id="ghNavSearch" class="gh__nav-search">

  <div class="pane-content">
    <div class="highwire-article-citation highwire-citation-type-highwire-article" data-node-nid="497341" id="node497341" data-pisa="sci;345/6194/1251788" data-pisa-master="sci;345/6194/1251788" data-apath="/sci/345/6194/1251788.atom" data-hw-author-tooltip-instance="highwire_author_tooltip"><div class="highwire-cite highwire-cite-highwire-article highwire-citation-jnl-sci-article clearfix has-author-tooltip">
  <header class="article__header">
        <div class="overline">Research Article</div>
            <h1 class="article__headline"><div class="highwire-cite-title">A chromosome-based draft sequence of the hexaploid bread wheat (<em>Triticum aestivum</em>) genome</div></h1>
            <div class="article__expandable-area collapsed">
      <div class="article byline byline--article"><div class="highwire-markup"><div xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" id="content-block-markup"><div xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" class="contributors"><ol class="contributor-list" id="contrib-group-1"><li class="last" id="contrib-1"><span class="collab" id="collab-1">The International Wheat Genome Sequencing Consortium (IWGSC)</span><a id="xref-fn-1-1" class="xref-fn" href="#fn-1">*</a><span class="xref-sep">,</span><a id="xref-corresp-1-1" class="xref-corresp" href="#corresp-1">&dagger;</a></li></ol><ol class="corresp-list"><li class="corresp" id="corresp-1"><a class="rev-xref" href="#xref-corresp-1-1">&crarr;</a><span class="corresp-label">&dagger;</span>Corresponding author: K. X. Mayer (<span class="em-link"><span class="em-addr">k.mayer{at}helmholtz-muenchen.de</span></span>)</li></ol></div><div xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" class="contributors"><ol class="contributor-list" id="contrib-group-2"></ol><ul class="author-notes"><li class="fn-current-aff" id="fn-1"><p id="p-1"><a class="rev-xref" href="#xref-fn-1-1">&crarr;</a><span class="fn-label">*</span> All authors with their affiliations appear at the end of this paper.</p></li></ul></div></div></div>
</div>
    </div>
    <p class="contributor-list__reveal">
      <span class="contributor-list__toggler"><b></b> <span class="collapsed-text">See all</span><span class="expanded-text">Hide</span> authors and affiliations</span>
    </p>
      </header>

  <div class="meta-line">
    <cite>Science&nbsp;</cite> 18 Jul 2014:<br />Vol. 345, Issue 6194, 1251788<br />DOI: 10.1126/science.1251788      </div>
</div>
<div id="hw-article-author-popups-node497341" style="display: none;"><div class="author-tooltip-0"><ul class="author-tooltip-find-more"><li class="author-corresp-email-link first last"><span>For correspondence:

      <ul class="tabs inline panels-ajax-tab tabbed__list"><li class="first"><a href="/content/345/6194/1251788" class="panels-ajax-tab-tab" data-panel-name="jnl_sci_tab_art" data-target-id="highwire_article_tabs" data-entity-context="node:497341" data-trigger="" data-url-enabled="1">Article</a><a href="/panels_ajax_tab/jnl_sci_tab_art/node:497341/1" rel="nofollow" style="display:none" class="js-crawler-link"></a></li>
<li><a href="/content/345/6194/1251788/tab-figures-data" class="panels-ajax-tab-tab" data-panel-name="jnl_sci_tab_data" data-target-id="highwire_article_tabs" data-entity-context="node:497341" data-trigger="tab-figures-data" data-url-enabled="1">Figures & Data</a><a href="/panels_ajax_tab/jnl_sci_tab_data/node:497341/1" rel="nofollow" style="display:none" class="js-crawler-link"></a></li>
<li><a href="/content/345/6194/1251788/tab-article-info" class="panels-ajax-tab-tab" data-panel-name="jnl_sci_tab_info" data-target-id="highwire_article_tabs" data-entity-context="node:497341" data-trigger="tab-article-info" data-url-enabled="1">Info & Metrics</a><a href="/panels_ajax_tab/jnl_sci_tab_info/node:497341/1" rel="nofollow" style="display:none" class="js-crawler-link"></a></li>
<li><a href="/content/345/6194/1251788/tab-e-letters" class="panels-ajax-tab-tab" data-panel-name="article_tab_eletters" data-target-id="highwire_article_tabs" data-entity-context="node:497341" data-trigger="tab-e-letters" data-url-enabled="1">eLetters</a><a href="/panels_ajax_tab/article_tab_eletters/node:497341/1" rel="nofollow" style="display:none" class="js-crawler-link"></a></li>
<li class="last"><a href="/content/345/6194/1251788/tab-pdf" class="panels-ajax-tab-tab" data-panel-name="jnl_sci_tab_pdf" data-target-id="highwire_article_tabs" data-entity-context="node:497341" data-trigger="tab-pdf" data-url-enabled="1"><i class="fa fa-file-pdf-o"></i> PDF</a><a href="/panels_ajax_tab/jnl_sci_tab_pdf/node:497341/1" rel="nofollow" style="display:none" class="js-crawler-link"></a></li>
</ul>  
</div>
<div class="panel-pane pane-highwire-panel-tabs-container article__body">
  
      
  
  <div class="pane-content">
    <div data-panels-ajax-tab-preloaded="jnl_sci_tab_art" id="panels-ajax-tab-container-highwire_article_tabs" class="panels-ajax-tab-container"><div class="panels-ajax-tab-loading" style ="display:none"><img class="loading" src="https://science.sciencemag.org/sites/all/modules/contrib/panels_ajax_tab/images/loading.gif" alt="Loading" title="Loading" /></div><div class="panels-ajax-tab-wrap-jnl_sci_tab_art"><div class="panel-display panel-1col clearfix" >
  <div class="panel-panel panel-col">
    <div><div class="panel-pane pane-highwire-markup">
  
      
  
  <div class="pane-content">
    <div class="highwire-markup"><div xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" id="content-block-markup" data-highwire-cite-ref-tooltip-instance="highwire_reflinks_tooltip" data-highwire-glossary-tooltip-instance="highwire_reflinks_tooltip" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"><div class="article fulltext-view "><span class="highwire-journal-article-marker-start"></span><div class="section abstract" id="abstract-1"><h2>Abstract</h2><p id="p-2">An ordered draft sequence of the 17-gigabase hexaploid bread wheat (<em>Triticum aestivum</em>) genome has been produced by sequencing isolated chromosome arms. We have annotated 124,201 gene loci distributed nearly evenly across the homeologous chromosomes and subgenomes. Comparative gene analysis of wheat subgenomes and extant diploid and tetraploid wheat relatives showed that high sequence similarity and structural conservation are retained, with limited gene loss, after polyploidization. However, across the genomes there was evidence of dynamic gene gain, loss, and duplication since the divergence of the wheat lineages. A high degree of transcriptional autonomy and no global dominance was found for the subgenomes. These insights into the genome biology of a polyploid crop provide a springboard for faster gene isolation, rapid genetic marker development, and precise breeding to meet the needs of increasing food demand worldwide.</p></div><div class="sci-custom wheat-minitoc" id="boxed-text-1"><p id="p-3"><a href="http://www.sciencemag.org/site/extra/wheatgenome/index.xhtml">Special section on the wheat genome</a></p></div><p id="p-4">Rich in protein, carbohydrates, and minerals, bread wheat (<em>Triticum aestivum</em> L.) is one of the world’s most important cereal grain crops, serving as the staple food source for 30% of the human population. Between 2000 and 2008, wheat production fell by 5.5% primarily because of climatic trends (<a id="xref-ref-1-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-1"><em>1</em></a>), and, in 5 of the past 10 years, worldwide wheat production was not sufficient to meet demand (<a id="xref-ref-2-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-2"><em>2</em></a>). With the global population projected to exceed 9 billion by 2050, researchers, breeders and growers are facing the challenge of increasing wheat production by about 70% to meet future demands (<a id="xref-ref-3-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-3"><em>3</em></a>, <a id="xref-ref-4-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-4"><em>4</em></a>). Concurrently, growers are facing rising fertilizer and other input costs, weather extremes resulting from climate change, increasing competition between food and nonfood uses, and declining annual yield growth (<a id="xref-ref-5-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-5"><em>5</em></a>). A rapid paradigm shift in science-based advances in wheat genetics and breeding, comparable to the first green revolution of the 1960s, will be essential to meet these challenges. As for other major cereal crops (rice, maize, and sorghum), new knowledge and molecular tools using a reference genome sequence of wheat are needed to underpin breeding to accelerate the development of new wheat varieties.</p><p id="p-5">One key factor in the success of wheat as a global food crop is its adaptability to a wide range of climatic conditions. This is attributable, in part, to its allohexaploid genome structure, which arose as a result of two polyploidization events (<a id="xref-fig-1-1" class="xref-fig" href="#F1">Fig. 1</a>). The first of these is estimated to have occurred several hundred thousand years ago and brought together the genomes of two diploid species related to the wild species <em>Triticum urartu</em> (2<em>n</em> = 2<em>x</em> = 14; AA; 2<em>n</em> is the number of chromosomes in each somatic cell and 2<em>x</em> is the basic chromosome number) and a species from the Sitopsis section of <em>Triticum</em> that is believed to be related to <em>Aegilops speltoides</em> (2<em>n</em> = 14; SS) (<a id="xref-ref-6-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-6"><em>6</em></a>). This hybridization formed the allotetraploid <em>Triticum turgidum</em> (2<em>n</em> = 4<em>x</em> = 28; AABB), an ancestor of wild emmer wheat cultivated in the Middle East and <em>T. turgidum</em> sp. <em>durum</em> grown for pasta today. A second hybridization event between <em>T. turgidum</em> and a diploid grass species, <em>Aegilops tauschii</em> (DD), produced the ancestral allohexaploid <em>T. aestivum</em> (2<em>n</em> = 6<em>x</em> = 42, AABBDD) (<a id="xref-ref-6-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-6"><em>6</em></a>, <a id="xref-ref-7-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-7"><em>7</em></a>), which has since been cultivated as bread wheat and accounts for over 95% of the wheat grown worldwide.</p><figure class="fig pos-float type-figure  odd figure figure--data" id="F1">
  <div class="figure__head highwire-figure">
    <div class="fig-inline"><a href="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F1.large.jpg?width=800&amp;height=600&amp;carousel=1" title="Schematic diagram of the relationships between wheat genomes with polyploidization history and genealogy. Names and nomenclature for the genomes are indicated within circles that provide a schematic representation of the chromosomal complement for each species. Time estimates are from Marcussen et al. (45). mya, million years ago." class="fragment-images colorbox-load" rel="gallery-fragment-images-492649046" data-figure-caption="&lt;div class=&quot;highwire-markup&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;fig-label&quot;&gt;Fig. 1&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;caption-title&quot;&gt;Schematic diagram of the relationships between wheat genomes with polyploidization history and genealogy.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;p id=&quot;p-6&quot; class=&quot;first-child&quot;&gt;Names and nomenclature for the genomes are indicated within circles that provide a schematic representation of the chromosomal complement for each species. Time estimates are from Marcussen &lt;em&gt;et al&lt;/em&gt;. (&lt;a id=&quot;xref-ref-45-1&quot; class=&quot;xref-bibr&quot; href=&quot;#ref-45&quot;&gt;&lt;em&gt;45&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/a&gt;). mya, million years ago.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;sb-div caption-clear&quot;/&gt;&lt;/div&gt;" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0"><span class="hw-responsive-img"><img class="fragment-image lazyload" aria-describedby="F1-caption" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7" data-src="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F1.medium.gif"/><noscript><img class="fragment-image" aria-describedby="F1-caption" src="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F1.medium.gif"/></noscript></span></a></div>        <div class="figure__options">
      <ul class="highwire-figure-links"><li class="0 first"><a href="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F1.large.jpg?download=true" class="highwire-figure-link highwire-figure-link-download link-icon" title="Download Fig. 1"><i class="fa fa-download"></i> <span class="title">Download high-res image</span></a></li>
<li class="1"><a href="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F1.large.jpg" class="highwire-figure-link highwire-figure-link-newtab link-icon" target="_blank"><i class="fa fa-external-link"></i> <span class="title">Open in new tab</span></a></li>
<li class="2 last"><a href="/highwire/powerpoint/572277" class="highwire-figure-link highwire-figure-link-ppt link-icon"><i class="fa fa-download"></i> <span class="title">Download Powerpoint</span></a></li>
</ul>    </div>
      </div>
    <figcaption class="fig-caption" id="F1-caption">
    <span class="fig-label">Fig. 1</span> <span class="caption-title">Schematic diagram of the relationships between wheat genomes with polyploidization history and genealogy.</span><p id="p-6" class="first-child">Names and nomenclature for the genomes are indicated within circles that provide a schematic representation of the chromosomal complement for each species. Time estimates are from Marcussen <em>et al</em>. (<a id="xref-ref-45-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-45"><em>45</em></a>). mya, million years ago.</p><div class="sb-div caption-clear"></div>  </figcaption>
  </figure><p id="p-7">With 21 pairs of chromosomes, bread wheat is structurally an allopolyploid with three homeologous sets of seven chromosomes in each of the A, B, and D subgenomes. Genetically, however, it behaves as a diploid because homeologous pairing is prevented through the action of <em>Ph</em> genes (<a id="xref-ref-8-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-8"><em>8</em></a>). Each of the subgenomes is large, about 5.5 Gb in size and carries, in addition to related sets of genes, a high proportion (&gt;80%) of highly repetitive transposable elements (TEs) (<a id="xref-ref-9-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-9"><em>9</em></a>, <a id="xref-ref-10-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-10"><em>10</em></a>).</p><p id="p-8">The large and repetitive nature of the genome has hindered the generation of a reference genome sequence for bread wheat. Early work focused primarily on coding sequences that represent less than 2% of the genome. Coordinated efforts generated over 1 million expressed sequence tags (ESTs), 40,000 unigenes (<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/dbEST/dbEST_summary.html">www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/dbEST/dbEST_summary.html</a>), and 17,000 full-length complementary DNA (cDNA) sequences (<a id="xref-ref-11-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-11"><em>11</em></a>). These resources have enabled studies of individual genes and facilitated the development of microarrays and marker sets for targeted gene association and expression studies (<a id="xref-ref-12-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-12"><em>12</em></a>–<a id="xref-ref-14-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-14"><em>14</em></a>). At least 7000 ESTs have been assigned to chromosome-specific bins (<a id="xref-ref-15-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-15"><em>15</em></a>), providing an initial view of subgenome localization and chromosomal organization and facilitating low-resolution mapping of traits. More recently, high-throughput low-cost sequencing technologies have been applied to assemble the gene space of <em>T. urartu</em> (<a id="xref-ref-16-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-16"><em>16</em></a>) and <em>Ae. tauschii</em> (<a id="xref-ref-17-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-17"><em>17</em></a>), two diploid species related to bread wheat (<a id="xref-fig-1-2" class="xref-fig" href="#F1">Fig. 1</a>). About 60,000 genic sequences were also putatively assigned to the bread wheat A, B, or D subgenomes by using assembled Illumina (Illumina, Incorporated, San Diego, CA) sequence data for <em>Triticum monococcum</em> and <em>Ae. tauschii</em> and cDNAs from <em>Ae. speltoides</em> to guide gene assemblies of fivefold whole-genome sequence reads from <em>T. aestivum</em> ‘Chinese Spring’ (<a id="xref-ref-18-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-18"><em>18</em></a>). These resources have contributed information about the genes of hexaploid wheat and its wild diploid relatives and have underpinned the development of large sets of single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) markers (<a id="xref-ref-19-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-19"><em>19</em></a>–<a id="xref-ref-21-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-21"><em>21</em></a>). To date, however, relatively little is known about the position and distribution of genes on each of the bread wheat chromosomes and their evolution during the polyploidization events that resulted in the emergence of the hexaploid species.</p><div class="section other1" id="sec-1"><h2 class="">Survey sequencing the bread wheat genome</h2><p id="p-9">We used aneuploid bread wheat lines derived from double ditelosomic stocks of the hexaploid wheat cultivar Chinese Spring (<a id="xref-ref-22-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-22"><em>22</em></a>) to isolate, sequence, and assemble de novo each individual chromosome arm [except for 3B, which was isolated and sequenced as a complete chromosome (<a id="xref-ref-23-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-23"><em>23</em></a>)]. This approach reduced the complexity of assembling a highly redundant genome and enabled the differentiation of genes present in multiple copies and highly conserved homologs. Each chromosome arm, representing between 1.3 and 3.3% of the genome (<a id="xref-ref-24-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-24"><em>24</em></a>), was purified by flow-cytometric sorting and sequenced to a depth of between 30× and 241× with Illumina technology platforms (<a id="xref-ref-25-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-25"><em>25</em></a>). The paired end sequence reads were assembled with the short-read de novo assembly tool ABySS (<a id="xref-ref-25-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-25"><em>25</em></a>, <a id="xref-ref-26-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-26"><em>26</em></a>). A high proportion of reads assembled into contigs of repetitive sequence less than 200 base pairs (bp) and were excluded from the final assembly of 10.2 Gb. The quality of the assemblies and purity of chromosome arm preparations were assessed by using alignment to bin-mapped ESTs (<a id="xref-ref-15-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-15"><em>15</em></a>) and to the virtual barley genome (<a id="xref-ref-27-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-27"><em>27</em></a>). Summary statistics for the chromosome arm assemblies are shown in <a id="xref-table-wrap-1-1" class="xref-table" href="#T1">Tables 1</a> to <a id="xref-table-wrap-3-1" class="xref-table" href="#T3">3</a>. Compared with cytogenetically estimated chromosome sizes (<a id="xref-ref-24-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-24"><em>24</em></a>), the sequence assemblies represent 61% of the genome sequence, with the L50 of repeat-masked assemblies ranging from 1.7 to 8.9 kb.</p><div id="T1" class="table pos-float"><div class="table-caption"><span class="table-label">Table 1</span> <span class="caption-title">Sequencing, assembly, and GenomeZipper statistics for wheat A genome chromosome arms.</span><p id="p-10" class="first-child">Sequence indicates the total assembled sequence (&gt;200 bp); number of contigs is after filtering of highly repetitive sequence assemblies; syntenic loci is the number of gene loci anchored to reference gene; and the last row is the number of total anchored gene loci. Blank entries in all tables indicate data not applicable; fl-cDNA, full-length cDNA; nonred., nonredundant.</p><div class="sb-div caption-clear"></div></div><div class="table-inline"><div class="callout"><span>View this table:</span><ul class="callout-links"><li><a href="/highwire/markup/572872/expansion?width=1000&amp;height=500&amp;iframe=true&amp;postprocessors=highwire_figures%2Chighwire_math%2Chighwire_embed" class="colorbox colorbox-load table-expand-popup" rel="gallery-fragment-tables" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0">View popup</a></li><li><a href="" class="table-expand-inline" data-table-url="/highwire/markup/572872/expansion?postprocessors=highwire_figures%2Chighwire_math%2Chighwire_embed" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0">View inline</a></li></ul></div></div></div><div id="T2" class="table pos-float"><div class="table-caption"><span class="table-label">Table 2</span> <span class="caption-title">Sequencing, assembly, and GenomeZipper statistics for wheat B genome chromosome arms.</span><p id="p-11" class="first-child">Sequence indicates the total assembled sequence (&gt;200 bp); number of contigs is after filtering of highly repetitive sequence assemblies; syntenic loci is the number of gene loci anchored to reference gene; and the last row is the number of total anchored gene loci.</p><div class="sb-div caption-clear"></div></div><div class="table-inline"><div class="callout"><span>View this table:</span><ul class="callout-links"><li><a href="/highwire/markup/572292/expansion?width=1000&amp;height=500&amp;iframe=true&amp;postprocessors=highwire_figures%2Chighwire_math%2Chighwire_embed" class="colorbox colorbox-load table-expand-popup" rel="gallery-fragment-tables" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0">View popup</a></li><li><a href="" class="table-expand-inline" data-table-url="/highwire/markup/572292/expansion?postprocessors=highwire_figures%2Chighwire_math%2Chighwire_embed" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0">View inline</a></li></ul></div></div></div><div id="T3" class="table pos-float"><div class="table-caption"><span class="table-label">Table 3</span> <span class="caption-title">Sequencing, assembly, and GenomeZipper statistics for wheat D genome chromosome arms.</span><p id="p-12" class="first-child">Sequence indicates the total assembled sequence (&gt;200 bp); number of contigs is after filtering of highly repetitive sequence assemblies; syntenic loci is the number of gene loci anchored to reference gene; and the last row is the number of total anchored gene loci.</p><div class="sb-div caption-clear"></div></div><div class="table-inline"><div class="callout"><span>View this table:</span><ul class="callout-links"><li><a href="/highwire/markup/572264/expansion?width=1000&amp;height=500&amp;iframe=true&amp;postprocessors=highwire_figures%2Chighwire_math%2Chighwire_embed" class="colorbox colorbox-load table-expand-popup" rel="gallery-fragment-tables" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0">View popup</a></li><li><a href="" class="table-expand-inline" data-table-url="/highwire/markup/572264/expansion?postprocessors=highwire_figures%2Chighwire_math%2Chighwire_embed" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0">View inline</a></li></ul></div></div></div></div><div class="section other2" id="sec-2"><h2 class="">Repetitive DNA</h2><p id="p-13">We assessed the TE and sequence repeat space across the whole wheat genome and compared the repeat content of the A, B, and D subgenomes (<a id="xref-ref-25-3" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-25"><em>25</em></a>). From the frequency of mathematically defined repeats (MDRs; 20mers) (<a id="xref-ref-28-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-28"><em>28</em></a>), we estimated that 24 to 26% of the sequence reads contain high copy number repeats, represented by 20mers with more than 1000 copies. In total, 81% of raw reads and 76.6% of assembled sequences contained repeats, the latter showing reduced representation of Gypsy long terminal repeat (LTR) retrotransposons, as well as Mutator and Mariner-type DNA transposons.</p><p id="p-14">Analysis of the distribution of transposons across the three subgenomes revealed that class I elements (retroelements) were more abundant in the A genome chromosomes relative to B or D (A &gt; B &gt; D), whereas class II elements (DNA transposons) showed the reverse (D &gt; B &gt; A). The most pronounced differences were observed between deteriorated and thus unclassifiable LTR retrotransposons, which showed a gradient of abundance across the subgenomes (A &gt; D &gt; B) distinct from other class I or class II elements. We hypothesize that unclassifiable LTR retrotransposons represent older (and thus more deteriorated) elements that were modified through polyploidization and ongoing TE amplification or degeneration. Assuming the amplification/degeneration dynamics are similar within each genome, the distribution of LTR retrotransposons across the three subgenomes suggest that the B genome progenitor contained a lower number of LTR retroelements and that transposon activity post-polyploidization has introduced a higher proportion of more recent amplifications into the B genome.</p><p id="p-15">We observed a substantial reduction (down to 19.6%) in the TE content associated with the 0.8% (615 Mb) of the chromosomal survey sequences (CSSs) representing contigs containing high-confidence genes (for definition see below) (<a id="xref-ref-25-4" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-25"><em>25</em></a>). The analysis revealed a marked depletion of all class I elements in the neighborhood of genes, with the exception of non-LTR retrotransposons, which were enriched twofold. CACTA transposons accounted for the greatest proportion of the observed 67% reduction in class II elements, whereas minor components, especially Harbinger and miniature inverted-repeat TEs, were enriched. Selective exclusion of high-copy transposons that undergo epigenetic silencing and reduce expression by heterochromatin spreading (<a id="xref-ref-29-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-29"><em>29</em></a>) may result in depletion of repeat element types in the vicinity of genes.</p></div><div class="section other3" id="sec-3"><h2 class="">miRNAs</h2><p id="p-16">A total of 270 different putative microRNA molecules (miRNAs) (49 not previously reported) were identified corresponding to 98,068 predicted miRNA-coding loci (<a id="xref-ref-25-5" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-25"><em>25</em></a>). Only 1668 loci (1.7%) evidenced expression on the basis of publicly available ESTs and of RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) data reported in this work, consistent with previous analyses in wheat (<a id="xref-ref-30-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-30"><em>30</em></a>, <a id="xref-ref-31-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-31"><em>31</em></a>). Similarly, we observed that class II DNA transposons, specifically TcMar transposons, were predominantly found in miRNAs. For 87% of the putative miRNA-coding loci, at least one putative target gene was identified in the wheat CSS. A total of 6615 predicted miRNA-coding sequences (44 with evidence of expression) were characterized by at least one mature sequence and one target site covered by the same repeat element. This suggests that an active miRNA could arise when an advantageous regulatory niche evolves from a series of random TE insertions and may represent a means by which a network of putative miRNAs and target genes may develop, even before miRNA activation (<a id="xref-ref-32-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-32"><em>32</em></a>).</p></div><div class="section other4" id="sec-4"><h2 class="">Protein-coding genes</h2><p id="p-17">Annotation of protein-coding gene sequences in the CSS assemblies had its basis in comparisons to annotated genes in related grasses [<em>Brachypodium distachyon</em> (<a id="xref-ref-33-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-33"><em>33</em></a>), <em>Oryza sativa</em> (<a id="xref-ref-34-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-34"><em>34</em></a>), <em>Sorghum bicolor</em> (<a id="xref-ref-35-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-35"><em>35</em></a>), and <em>Hordeum vulgare</em> (<a id="xref-ref-27-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-27"><em>27</em></a>)], as well as publically available wheat full-length cDNAs (fl-cDNAs) (<a id="xref-ref-11-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-11"><em>11</em></a>) and RNA-seq data generated from five tissues of a Chinese Spring cultivar at three different developmental stages. Briefly, the reference grass coding sequences and wheat transcript resources were mapped separately to assembled CSS contigs, and the alignments were merged to define the exact coordinates of gene loci, alternative splicing forms, and transcripts with no similarity to related grass genes (<a id="xref-ref-25-6" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-25"><em>25</em></a>).</p><p id="p-18">This analysis identified 976,962 loci with 1,265,548 distinct splicing variants. A total of 133,090 loci showing homology to related grass genes were classified as high confidence (HC) gene calls. These were further subdivided into four groups (HC1 to HC4) on the basis of the proportion of the length of the reference gene covered by a predicted locus. Of these, 124,201 (93.3%) genes were annotated on individual chromosome arm sequences, and the remaining 6.7% corresponded to wheat transcripts, which were not detected in the CSS assemblies (<a id="xref-fig-2-1" class="xref-fig" href="#F2">Fig. 2A</a>). In total, 55,249 (44%) of the loci assigned to chromosomes were classified as HC1, that is, representing functional genes spanning at least 70% of the length of the supporting evidence (<a id="xref-table-wrap-4-1" class="xref-table" href="#T4">Table 4</a>). The remaining 56% of HC genes comprised genes that were fragmented in the assembly and thus could only be partially structurally defined or were classified as gene fragments and pseudogenes. We expect that many of these will be merged as further sequencing improves the coverage and quality of genic sequences. On the basis of the level of completion of the assembly and the detection rate of HC1 genes (<a id="xref-ref-25-7" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-25"><em>25</em></a>), we estimated that the wheat genome contains 106,000 functional protein-coding genes. This supports gene number estimates ranging between 32,000 and 38,000 for each diploid subgenome in hexaploid wheat and is consistent with findings in related diploid species (<a id="xref-ref-16-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-16"><em>16</em></a>–<a id="xref-ref-18-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-18"><em>18</em></a>, <a id="xref-ref-20-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-20"><em>20</em></a>, <a id="xref-ref-36-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-36"><em>36</em></a>).</p><figure class="fig pos-float type-figure  odd figure figure--data" id="F2">
  <div class="figure__head highwire-figure">
    <div class="fig-inline"><a href="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F2.large.jpg?width=800&amp;height=600&amp;carousel=1" title="Gene content, density, synteny, structural conservation, and tandemly duplicated genes. (A) Total number of HC bread wheat genes identified on the A (green), B (purple), and D (orange) subgenomes (left) and their distribution on individual chromosome arms or chromosomes (in the case of group 3) (right). (B) Syntenic conservation of HC and LC genes for each chromosome arm defined by the ratio of the number of genes anchored in the GenomeZipper and the number of annotated genes normalized per Mb of physical chromosome(-arm) size. Solid lines visualize average syntenic conservation for LC (black) and HC (red) genes, and dashed lines give isochores for different percentages of synteny. (C) Conservation of gene family composition between single chromosome arms. Color-coding in the outer ring indicates relatedness of the respective branches (A/D &gt; B, light orange; A/B &gt; D, light blue; B/D &gt; A, light red). Red asterisks mark edges with boot-strapping values &gt; 0.95. (D) Proportion of lineage-specific, intrachromosomally duplicated genes in the wheat genome compared with other grass genomes. Error bars indicate deviations among individual chromosomes." class="fragment-images colorbox-load" rel="gallery-fragment-images-492649046" data-figure-caption="&lt;div class=&quot;highwire-markup&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;fig-label&quot;&gt;Fig. 2&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;caption-title&quot;&gt;Gene content, density, synteny, structural conservation, and tandemly duplicated genes.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;p id=&quot;p-19&quot; class=&quot;first-child&quot;&gt;(&lt;strong&gt;A&lt;/strong&gt;) Total number of HC bread wheat genes identified on the A (green), B (purple), and D (orange) subgenomes (left) and their distribution on individual chromosome arms or chromosomes (in the case of group 3) (right). (&lt;strong&gt;B&lt;/strong&gt;) Syntenic conservation of HC and LC genes for each chromosome arm defined by the ratio of the number of genes anchored in the GenomeZipper and the number of annotated genes normalized per Mb of physical chromosome(-arm) size. Solid lines visualize average syntenic conservation for LC (black) and HC (red) genes, and dashed lines give isochores for different percentages of synteny. (&lt;strong&gt;C&lt;/strong&gt;) Conservation of gene family composition between single chromosome arms. Color-coding in the outer ring indicates relatedness of the respective branches (A/D &gt; B, light orange; A/B &gt; D, light blue; B/D &gt; A, light red). Red asterisks mark edges with boot-strapping values &gt; 0.95. (&lt;strong&gt;D&lt;/strong&gt;) Proportion of lineage-specific, intrachromosomally duplicated genes in the wheat genome compared with other grass genomes. Error bars indicate deviations among individual chromosomes.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;sb-div caption-clear&quot;/&gt;&lt;/div&gt;" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0"><span class="hw-responsive-img"><img class="fragment-image lazyload" aria-describedby="F2-caption" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7" data-src="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F2.medium.gif"/><noscript><img class="fragment-image" aria-describedby="F2-caption" src="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F2.medium.gif"/></noscript></span></a></div>        <div class="figure__options">
      <ul class="highwire-figure-links"><li class="0 first"><a href="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F2.large.jpg?download=true" class="highwire-figure-link highwire-figure-link-download link-icon" title="Download Fig. 2"><i class="fa fa-download"></i> <span class="title">Download high-res image</span></a></li>
<li class="1"><a href="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F2.large.jpg" class="highwire-figure-link highwire-figure-link-newtab link-icon" target="_blank"><i class="fa fa-external-link"></i> <span class="title">Open in new tab</span></a></li>
<li class="2 last"><a href="/highwire/powerpoint/572243" class="highwire-figure-link highwire-figure-link-ppt link-icon"><i class="fa fa-download"></i> <span class="title">Download Powerpoint</span></a></li>
</ul>    </div>
      </div>
    <figcaption class="fig-caption" id="F2-caption">
    <span class="fig-label">Fig. 2</span> <span class="caption-title">Gene content, density, synteny, structural conservation, and tandemly duplicated genes.</span><p id="p-19" class="first-child">(<strong>A</strong>) Total number of HC bread wheat genes identified on the A (green), B (purple), and D (orange) subgenomes (left) and their distribution on individual chromosome arms or chromosomes (in the case of group 3) (right). (<strong>B</strong>) Syntenic conservation of HC and LC genes for each chromosome arm defined by the ratio of the number of genes anchored in the GenomeZipper and the number of annotated genes normalized per Mb of physical chromosome(-arm) size. Solid lines visualize average syntenic conservation for LC (black) and HC (red) genes, and dashed lines give isochores for different percentages of synteny. (<strong>C</strong>) Conservation of gene family composition between single chromosome arms. Color-coding in the outer ring indicates relatedness of the respective branches (A/D &gt; B, light orange; A/B &gt; D, light blue; B/D &gt; A, light red). Red asterisks mark edges with boot-strapping values &gt; 0.95. (<strong>D</strong>) Proportion of lineage-specific, intrachromosomally duplicated genes in the wheat genome compared with other grass genomes. Error bars indicate deviations among individual chromosomes.</p><div class="sb-div caption-clear"></div>  </figcaption>
  </figure><div id="T4" class="table pos-float"><div class="table-caption"><span class="table-label">Table 4</span> <span class="caption-title">Characteristics of HC bread wheat genes.</span><p id="p-20" class="first-child">Distinct exons means that exons of two or more transcripts were counted once if they had identical start and stop positions; mean transcripts and mean exons are transcripts per locus and exons per locus, respectively; the second mean exons row shows exons per transcript.</p><div class="sb-div caption-clear"></div></div><div class="table-inline"><div class="callout"><span>View this table:</span><ul class="callout-links"><li><a href="/highwire/markup/572271/expansion?width=1000&amp;height=500&amp;iframe=true&amp;postprocessors=highwire_figures%2Chighwire_math%2Chighwire_embed" class="colorbox colorbox-load table-expand-popup" rel="gallery-fragment-tables" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0">View popup</a></li><li><a href="" class="table-expand-inline" data-table-url="/highwire/markup/572271/expansion?postprocessors=highwire_figures%2Chighwire_math%2Chighwire_embed" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0">View inline</a></li></ul></div></div></div><p id="p-21">Consistent with observations of high levels of non–protein-coding loci in both plants (<a id="xref-ref-27-3" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-27"><em>27</em></a>, <a id="xref-ref-37-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-37"><em>37</em></a>) and animals (<a id="xref-ref-38-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-38"><em>38</em></a>), 890,576 loci did not share any, or only low, similarity with related grass genes. Loci with low sequence similarity (88,998) were defined as low-confidence (LC) genes, and the remainder were classified as repeat-associated, noncoding, or non–homology-supported loci (<a id="xref-ref-25-8" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-25"><em>25</em></a>). More than 96% of public wheat ESTs (HarvEST) mapped to the CSS gene sets (BLASTN; <em>E</em> value &lt;10<sup>−10</sup>), including 89% that correspond to HC gene-coding loci, demonstrating that the CSS assemblies contain a high representation of the current gene inventory of the bread wheat genome.</p><p id="p-22">Our analysis revealed that 49% of the HC genes exhibit alternative splicing (AS) with an average of 2.6 transcripts per locus. This may be an underestimation, because 69% of the most complete gene loci (HC1) were alternatively spliced with an average of 3.5 transcripts per locus. Evidence that additional AS variants will be identified has already emerged from a preliminary assessment of gene structure prediction using proteomics analyses. In a study of 63 genes, 50 (81%) structures were confirmed, 8 (13%) provided evidence for alternative gene structures, whereas 5 were absent in the structural gene calls. Extrapolating these data to the whole genome, we estimate that hexaploid bread wheat encodes more than 300,000 distinctive protein-coding transcripts. The proportion of genes exhibiting AS appeared to be similar in all three subgenomes and is consistent with the transcriptional complexity reported for plant species such as <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em> (<a id="xref-ref-39-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-39"><em>39</em></a>) and <em>H</em>. <em>vulgare</em> (<a id="xref-ref-27-4" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-27"><em>27</em></a>).</p></div><div class="section other5" id="sec-5"><h2 class="">Gene distribution and order</h2><p id="p-23">Analysis of the gene distribution across the three subgenomes revealed a higher number of gene loci on the B subgenome (44,523; 35%) compared with the A and D subgenomes, which contained 40,253 (33%) and 39,425 (32%), respectively (<a id="xref-fig-2-2" class="xref-fig" href="#F2">Fig. 2A</a>). This distribution was not consistent at the chromosomal level. For example, the gene distribution across homeologous group 3 chromosomes is 30% 3A, 42% 3B, and 28% 3D, whereas in homeologous group 7 the D genome contains the highest proportion of genes. These observations may reflect preexisting differences in the subgenomes before polyploidization or indicate that drivers determining the composition of the genome do not act at the subgenome level but regionally.</p><p id="p-24">Up to 2.4-fold variation in gene density was observed on different chromosome arms, ranging from 4.4 loci per Mb (5AS) up to 10.4 loci per Mb (2DL) (<a id="xref-fig-2-3" class="xref-fig" href="#F2">Fig. 2B</a>). Consistent with observations in rye (<a id="xref-ref-40-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-40"><em>40</em></a>) and the complete sequence of wheat chromosome 3B (<a id="xref-ref-23-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-23"><em>23</em></a>), on average 53.2% of the HC genes were located on syntenic chromosomes compared to <em>B</em>. <em>distachyon</em> (Bd), <em>O</em>. <em>sativa</em> (Os), and <em>S</em>. <em>bicolor</em> (Sb). The average level of synteny for genes located on the D genome chromosomes (58%) was higher than the average for those on the A (51%) and the B (50%) chromosomes. Sequence conservation in LC genes is low, and, in comparison to HC genes, reduced syntenic conservation is observed. Thus, although the majority of LC genes are likely to result from the frequent generation of gene fragments by double-strand repair mechanisms or are deteriorated (pseudo)genes that were fragmented after the divergence from the other sequenced grass genomes (<a id="xref-ref-10-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-10"><em>10</em></a>), the retained synteny to other grass genomes suggests that some LC genes may be functional.</p><p id="p-25">To determine the extent of gene conservation across homeologous chromosomes, we clustered the HC genes into protein families by sequence similarity (<a id="xref-fig-2-4" class="xref-fig" href="#F2">Fig. 2C</a>) (<a id="xref-ref-25-9" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-25"><em>25</em></a>). With the exception of chromosome 4AL, the genes on all chromosome arms clustered with their corresponding homologs. The pattern of clustering observed for 4A is consistent with a known pericentromeric inversion and two translocations of segments from chromosome arms 5AL and 7BS (<a id="xref-ref-41-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-41"><em>41</em></a>, <a id="xref-ref-42-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-42"><em>42</em></a>). All possible cluster topologies were found between genes on the A, B, and D genomes. Overall, the patterns of conservation suggest that the gene content of the A and B homeologous chromosomes is more similar to the D genome chromosomes than to each other. This observation contradicts a model of bifurcating evolutionary relationships between the A, B, and D genomes but is consistent with models of interlineage hybridization (i.e., reticulate evolution) in the Triticeae (<a id="xref-ref-43-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-43"><em>43</em></a>, <a id="xref-ref-44-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-44"><em>44</em></a>) and corroborate phylogenomic analyses that suggest that the D genome is a product of homoploid hybrid speciation between A and B genome ancestors &gt;5 million years ago (<a id="xref-ref-45-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-45"><em>45</em></a>). Although the potential for preexisting differences needs to be considered, the preservation of gene copies in each of the A, B, and D genomes provides evidence for their structural autonomy, a likely consequence of independent pairing during meiosis (<a id="xref-ref-46-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-46"><em>46</em></a>). A high degree of subgenome autonomy was also reflected in the observed patterns of gene expression (see below).</p><p id="p-26">We used two independent but complementary approaches to generate an order for the many small contigs that comprise the chromosome arm assemblies (<a id="xref-ref-25-10" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-25"><em>25</em></a>). The GenomeZipper approach (<a id="xref-ref-47-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-47"><em>47</em></a>) combines the syntenic conservation of gene order in grasses (<a id="xref-ref-48-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-48"><em>48</em></a>) and the known gene orders of fully sequenced grass genomes (<a id="xref-ref-33-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-33"><em>33</em></a>–<a id="xref-ref-35-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-35"><em>35</em></a>) with high-density SNP-based genetic maps (<a id="xref-ref-21-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-21"><em>21</em></a>, <a id="xref-ref-49-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-49"><em>49</em></a>) to create a virtual gene order in wheat. The number of genes anchored per chromosome (chr.) ranged from 2125 (chr. 6B) to 4404 (chr. 2D) (<a id="xref-table-wrap-1-2" class="xref-table" href="#T1">Table 1</a>). Overall, the GenomeZipper inferred positions of 21,221, 22,051, and 22,813 genes, respectively, in the A, B, and D genomes. To complement this, the POPSEQ approach (<a id="xref-ref-50-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-50"><em>50</em></a>) was used to build an ultradense genetic map comprising 13.3 million SNPs identified after shallow-coverage whole-genome sequencing of 90 doubled haploid individuals of the synthetic W7984 × Opata M85 population (<a id="xref-ref-51-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-51"><em>51</em></a>). This map assigned a partially overlapping set of 17,297, 21,101, and 17,997 HC genes, respectively, to the individual chromosomes of the A, B, and D genomes. The POPSEQ genetic map showed concordance with the gene assignments to flow-sorted chromosomes (99.4%) and the GenomeZipper (99.8%). The two inferred gene orders along chromosomes were also largely collinear (Spearman’s correlation coefficient = 0.85). From both anchored data sets, we were able to position a nonredundant set of 75,183 HC genes on the 21 chromosomes of bread wheat by genetic mapping and/or syntenic conservation.</p><p id="p-27">Gene duplication is frequently observed in plant genomes, arising from polyploidization or through tandem or segmental duplication associated with replication (<a id="xref-ref-52-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-52"><em>52</em></a>). For each wheat chromosome, the percentage of genes that have undergone lineage-specific intrachromosomal duplication was determined with OrthoMCL (<a id="xref-ref-53-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-53"><em>53</em></a>). By using the HC1 genes, we estimated that between 19.1% (chr. 7B) and 29.7% (chr. 2B) (23.6% average for all chromosomes) of the genes are duplicated on each chromosome (<a id="xref-ref-25-11" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-25"><em>25</em></a>). Comparison of the number of duplicated genes identified by this analysis for chr. 3B (25.3% of HC1 genes) with the 3B reference pseudomolecule (37% duplicated genes) (<a id="xref-ref-23-3" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-23"><em>23</em></a>) indicated that we are likely underestimating the number of duplicated genes. This is due to the fragmented nature of the assemblies obtained from whole-genome or chromosome-shotgun sequences that collapse highly conserved duplicates. No significant differences in the proportion of duplicates were observed between the three subgenomes (χ<sup>2</sup> test, χ<sup>2</sup> = 3.8, <em>P</em> = 0.15).</p><p id="p-28">For each chromosome, an average of 73% of the duplicates are located on one of the chromosome arms, suggesting that they may be tandem duplicates that arise through unequal crossing-over and replication-dependent chromosome breakage (<a id="xref-ref-54-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-54"><em>54</em></a>) or through the activity of transposable elements. When compared with the percentage of intrachromosomal duplicates found in rice, sorghum, barley, maize, and foxtail millet (17 to 20%) (<a id="xref-ref-27-5" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-27"><em>27</em></a>, <a id="xref-ref-33-3" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-33"><em>33</em></a>–<a id="xref-ref-35-3" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-35"><em>35</em></a>, <a id="xref-ref-55-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-55"><em>55</em></a>, <a id="xref-ref-56-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-56"><em>56</em></a>), the proportion of gene duplications in wheat was significantly higher (<a id="xref-fig-2-5" class="xref-fig" href="#F2">Fig. 2D</a>; Tukey’s honest significant difference, pairwise <em>P</em> &lt; 0.007).</p></div><div class="section other6" id="sec-6"><h2 class="">Comparisons with related species</h2><p id="p-29">We assembled sequence data from seven species related to progenitors of the bread wheat A, B, and D subgenomes (<a id="xref-ref-25-12" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-25"><em>25</em></a>). Illumina whole-genome sequence data and assemblies were generated from two tetraploid wheat cultivars (AABB) <em>T. turgidum</em> ‘Cappelli’ (originating from Italy) and <em>T. turgidum</em> ‘Strongfield’ (originating from Canada) as well as from the diploid genome of <em>Ae. speltoides</em> (SS). These data were combined with whole-genome sequence data from <em>T. urartu</em> (AA<sup>uu</sup>) (<a id="xref-ref-16-3" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-16"><em>16</em></a>), <em>T. monococcum (</em>AA<sup>mm</sup>), <em>Ae. tauschii</em> (DD) (<a id="xref-ref-17-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-17"><em>17</em></a>), and <em>Aegilops sharonensis</em> (S<sup>sh</sup>S<sup>sh</sup>). For the unannotated genomes of <em>T. turgidum</em>, <em>T. monococcum</em>, <em>Ae. speltoides</em>, and <em>Ae. sharonensis</em>, proteins of annotated grass genomes (<a id="xref-ref-27-6" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-27"><em>27</em></a>, <a id="xref-ref-33-4" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-33"><em>33</em></a>, <a id="xref-ref-35-4" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-35"><em>35</em></a>, <a id="xref-ref-57-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-57"><em>57</em></a>) and <em>T. aestivum</em> gene models were projected on the sequence assemblies.</p><p id="p-30">Genes and gene families in the hexaploid, tetraploid, and diploid genomes were then compared to assess the dynamics of gene retention or loss after polyploidization and to define the core wheat genes. When comparing the sizes of gene families in <em>Ae. tauschii</em> (<a id="xref-ref-17-3" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-17"><em>17</em></a>) and <em>T. urartu</em> (<a id="xref-ref-16-4" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-16"><em>16</em></a>) diploid genomes with the individual subgenomes of hexaploid wheat (<a id="xref-fig-3-1" class="xref-fig" href="#F3">Fig. 3, A and B</a>), we found that gene loss mainly affected genes belonging to expanded families, consistent with previous observations (<a id="xref-ref-18-3" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-18"><em>18</em></a>). In contrast, singletons (i.e., genes without paralogous copies within the same genome) were not usually subject to gene loss after polyploidization. Pronounced variations of gene copy retention or loss patterns were observed depending on the gene family considered.</p><figure class="fig pos-float type-figure  odd figure figure--data" id="F3">
  <div class="figure__head highwire-figure">
    <div class="fig-inline"><a href="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F3.large.jpg?width=800&amp;height=600&amp;carousel=1" title="Gene conservation and the wheat pan- and core genes. (A and B) Relationship between gene family sizes in diploid Ae. tauschii (A) and T. urartu (B) and each subgenome of hexaploid bread wheat (colors as in Fig. 2A). Boxes visualize the lower and upper quartiles of gene family sizes. Color intensity indicates the number of gene families in the respective bin. The black line shows a 1:1 gene copy number relationship for bread wheat, Ae. tauschii, and T. urartu, and colored lines show the regression fit for observed gene family size in the wheat subgenomes. (C) Percentages of genes of the bread wheat subgenomes that show significant sequence similarity to other genomes: Core genes correspond to genes with hits to all subgenomes as well as to T. turgidum and all diploid related progenitor genomes; shared genes&#x2013;T. aestivum are genes with hits to any other T. aestivum subgenome but not to T. turgidum or any of the closest diploid relatives; shared genes&#x2013;T. turgidum correspond to genes with hits to T. turgidum but not to any of the closest diploid relatives; shared genes&#x2013;lineage, with hits to the subgenome&#x2019;s closest relative genome but not to T. turgidum or any of the other closest related genomes." class="fragment-images colorbox-load" rel="gallery-fragment-images-492649046" data-figure-caption="&lt;div class=&quot;highwire-markup&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;fig-label&quot;&gt;Fig. 3&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;caption-title&quot;&gt;Gene conservation and the wheat pan- and core genes.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;p id=&quot;p-31&quot; class=&quot;first-child&quot;&gt;(&lt;strong&gt;A&lt;/strong&gt; and &lt;strong&gt;B&lt;/strong&gt;) Relationship between gene family sizes in diploid &lt;em&gt;Ae. tauschii&lt;/em&gt; (A) and &lt;em&gt;T. urartu&lt;/em&gt; (B) and each subgenome of hexaploid bread wheat (colors as in &lt;a id=&quot;xref-fig-2-6&quot; class=&quot;xref-fig&quot; href=&quot;#F2&quot;&gt;Fig. 2A&lt;/a&gt;). Boxes visualize the lower and upper quartiles of gene family sizes. Color intensity indicates the number of gene families in the respective bin. The black line shows a 1:1 gene copy number relationship for bread wheat, &lt;em&gt;Ae. tauschii&lt;/em&gt;, and &lt;em&gt;T. urartu&lt;/em&gt;, and colored lines show the regression fit for observed gene family size in the wheat subgenomes. (&lt;strong&gt;C&lt;/strong&gt;) Percentages of genes of the bread wheat subgenomes that show significant sequence similarity to other genomes: Core genes correspond to genes with hits to all subgenomes as well as to &lt;em&gt;T. turgidum&lt;/em&gt; and all diploid related progenitor genomes; shared genes&#x2013;&lt;em&gt;T. aestivum&lt;/em&gt; are genes with hits to any other &lt;em&gt;T. aestivum&lt;/em&gt; subgenome but not to &lt;em&gt;T. turgidum&lt;/em&gt; or any of the closest diploid relatives; shared genes&#x2013;&lt;em&gt;T. turgidum&lt;/em&gt; correspond to genes with hits to &lt;em&gt;T. turgidum&lt;/em&gt; but not to any of the closest diploid relatives; shared genes&#x2013;lineage, with hits to the subgenome&#x2019;s closest relative genome but not to &lt;em&gt;T. turgidum&lt;/em&gt; or any of the other closest related genomes.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;sb-div caption-clear&quot;/&gt;&lt;/div&gt;" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0"><span class="hw-responsive-img"><img class="fragment-image lazyload" aria-describedby="F3-caption" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7" data-src="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F3.medium.gif"/><noscript><img class="fragment-image" aria-describedby="F3-caption" src="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F3.medium.gif"/></noscript></span></a></div>        <div class="figure__options">
      <ul class="highwire-figure-links"><li class="0 first"><a href="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F3.large.jpg?download=true" class="highwire-figure-link highwire-figure-link-download link-icon" title="Download Fig. 3"><i class="fa fa-download"></i> <span class="title">Download high-res image</span></a></li>
<li class="1"><a href="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F3.large.jpg" class="highwire-figure-link highwire-figure-link-newtab link-icon" target="_blank"><i class="fa fa-external-link"></i> <span class="title">Open in new tab</span></a></li>
<li class="2 last"><a href="/highwire/powerpoint/572251" class="highwire-figure-link highwire-figure-link-ppt link-icon"><i class="fa fa-download"></i> <span class="title">Download Powerpoint</span></a></li>
</ul>    </div>
      </div>
    <figcaption class="fig-caption" id="F3-caption">
    <span class="fig-label">Fig. 3</span> <span class="caption-title">Gene conservation and the wheat pan- and core genes.</span><p id="p-31" class="first-child">(<strong>A</strong> and <strong>B</strong>) Relationship between gene family sizes in diploid <em>Ae. tauschii</em> (A) and <em>T. urartu</em> (B) and each subgenome of hexaploid bread wheat (colors as in <a id="xref-fig-2-6" class="xref-fig" href="#F2">Fig. 2A</a>). Boxes visualize the lower and upper quartiles of gene family sizes. Color intensity indicates the number of gene families in the respective bin. The black line shows a 1:1 gene copy number relationship for bread wheat, <em>Ae. tauschii</em>, and <em>T. urartu</em>, and colored lines show the regression fit for observed gene family size in the wheat subgenomes. (<strong>C</strong>) Percentages of genes of the bread wheat subgenomes that show significant sequence similarity to other genomes: Core genes correspond to genes with hits to all subgenomes as well as to <em>T. turgidum</em> and all diploid related progenitor genomes; shared genes–<em>T. aestivum</em> are genes with hits to any other <em>T. aestivum</em> subgenome but not to <em>T. turgidum</em> or any of the closest diploid relatives; shared genes–<em>T. turgidum</em> correspond to genes with hits to <em>T. turgidum</em> but not to any of the closest diploid relatives; shared genes–lineage, with hits to the subgenome’s closest relative genome but not to <em>T. turgidum</em> or any of the other closest related genomes.</p><div class="sb-div caption-clear"></div>  </figcaption>
  </figure><p id="p-32">Highly similar gene retention rates were found for all bread wheat subgenomes in comparison to <em>Ae. tauschii</em> and <em>T. urartu</em> [0.91 (A), 0.94 (B), and 0.89 (D) versus <em>Ae. tauschii</em> and 0.91 (A), 0.96 (B), and 0.91 (D) versus <em>T. urartu</em>] (<a id="xref-fig-3-2" class="xref-fig" href="#F3">Fig. 3, A and B</a>). The extent of gene loss in the D subgenome, the most recent addition to the hexaploid genome, appeared slightly lower than the more ancient A and B subgenomes. Thus, as observed for the gene content and structural similarities between individual chromosome arms, we found no evidence for a gradual gene loss induced by polyploidization. This may indicate that gene loss occurred rapidly after polyploid formation, followed by stabilization of gene content consistent with observations in newly created polyploids (<a id="xref-ref-58-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-58"><em>58</em></a>, <a id="xref-ref-59-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-59"><em>59</em></a>) and gene retention in cotton (<a id="xref-ref-60-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-60"><em>60</em></a>).</p><p id="p-33">We conducted a clustering analysis of gene families and determined the number of genes in the bread wheat subgenomes that have an ortholog in the genomes from the A genome lineage (<em>T. urartu</em> and <em>T. monococcum</em>), the closest known relatives for the B lineage (<em>Ae. sharonensis</em> and <em>Ae. speltoides</em>), the D lineage (<em>Ae. tauschii</em>), as well as in the tetraploid <em>T. turgidum</em> genome (<a id="xref-fig-3-3" class="xref-fig" href="#F3">Fig. 3C</a>). We found that the A, B, and D subgenomes contain very similar proportions of genes (60.1 to 61.3%) with orthologs in all the related diploid genomes. We also estimated the contribution of unique genes of the three subgenomes to the bread wheat genome. Because the absence of a particular gene in a single species could be due to incomplete sequence coverage or assembly errors, only lineage-specific gene family absence was considered in the analysis. Only a small fraction of the genes (1.3 to 1.7%) were specific to the A, B, or D lineages, demarcating the likely upper estimate of unique genes or gene families added to the bread wheat gene complement by the individual subgenomes.</p><p id="p-34">High sequence similarity between genes in the bread wheat subgenomes impedes efficient marker development and the identification of nonsynonymous sequence variations that can potentially affect gene or protein functionality. We delineated single-nucleotide variations (SNVs) between the bread wheat genes and the diploid and tetraploid related genomes and reconstructed phylogenetic relationships by using unrooted parsimony (<a id="xref-fig-4-1" class="xref-fig" href="#F4">Fig. 4A</a>) (<a id="xref-ref-25-13" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-25"><em>25</em></a>). In total, 11,435 SNVs within 6498 genes were specific to bread wheat and thus have likely been introduced after the second polyploidization event. Although most relationships support the known phylogeny of wheat, <em>Ae. sharonensis</em> was placed closer to the bread wheat D subgenome and <em>Ae. tauschii</em> than to <em>Ae. speltoides</em> and the B genome branch. This suggests that the Sitopsis group, which includes <em>Ae. sharonensis</em> and <em>Ae. speltoides</em>, is deeply furcated and related to both D and B genome branches.</p><figure class="fig pos-float type-figure  odd figure figure--data" id="F4">
  <div class="figure__head highwire-figure">
    <div class="fig-inline"><a href="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F4.large.jpg?width=800&amp;height=600&amp;carousel=1" title="Molecular evolution of the wheat lineage. SNVs were identified for coding sequences of bread wheat genes (TaAA, TaBB, and TaDD) against diploid T. monococcum (AAmm), T. urartu (AAuu), Ae. speltoides (SS), Ae. sharonensis (SshSsh), Ae. tauschii (DD), and tetraploid T. turgidum (AABB). (A) Unrooted phylogeny constructed on the basis of SNVs between bread wheat and its diploid or tetraploid relatives. The respective number of SNVs in each phylogenetic internodes is indicated with bar charts (scale at bottom left corner); colors indicate the respective bread wheat subgenome as in Fig. 2A. (B) Genes with stop codons in the respective related diploid genomes in comparison to the bread wheat A, B, and D subgenomes. Numbers in node connectors or in the center correspond to the number of introduced stop codons found in two (node connectors) or all (center) related genomes. (C) Chromosomal distribution of sequence identity between bread wheat genes and the diploid and tetraploid relatives for homeologous chromosomes." class="fragment-images colorbox-load" rel="gallery-fragment-images-492649046" data-figure-caption="&lt;div class=&quot;highwire-markup&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;fig-label&quot;&gt;Fig. 4&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;caption-title&quot;&gt;Molecular evolution of the wheat lineage.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;p id=&quot;p-35&quot; class=&quot;first-child&quot;&gt;SNVs were identified for coding sequences of bread wheat genes (TaAA, TaBB, and TaDD) against diploid &lt;em&gt;T. monococcum&lt;/em&gt; (AA&lt;sup&gt;mm&lt;/sup&gt;), &lt;em&gt;T. urartu&lt;/em&gt; (AA&lt;sup&gt;uu&lt;/sup&gt;), &lt;em&gt;Ae. speltoides&lt;/em&gt; (SS), &lt;em&gt;Ae. sharonensis&lt;/em&gt; (SshSsh), &lt;em&gt;Ae. tauschii&lt;/em&gt; (DD), and tetraploid &lt;em&gt;T. turgidum&lt;/em&gt; (AABB). (&lt;strong&gt;A&lt;/strong&gt;) Unrooted phylogeny constructed on the basis of SNVs between bread wheat and its diploid or tetraploid relatives. The respective number of SNVs in each phylogenetic internodes is indicated with bar charts (scale at bottom left corner); colors indicate the respective bread wheat subgenome as in &lt;a id=&quot;xref-fig-2-7&quot; class=&quot;xref-fig&quot; href=&quot;#F2&quot;&gt;Fig. 2A&lt;/a&gt;. (&lt;strong&gt;B&lt;/strong&gt;) Genes with stop codons in the respective related diploid genomes in comparison to the bread wheat A, B, and D subgenomes. Numbers in node connectors or in the center correspond to the number of introduced stop codons found in two (node connectors) or all (center) related genomes. (&lt;strong&gt;C&lt;/strong&gt;) Chromosomal distribution of sequence identity between bread wheat genes and the diploid and tetraploid relatives for homeologous chromosomes.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;sb-div caption-clear&quot;/&gt;&lt;/div&gt;" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0"><span class="hw-responsive-img"><img class="fragment-image lazyload" aria-describedby="F4-caption" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7" data-src="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F4.medium.gif"/><noscript><img class="fragment-image" aria-describedby="F4-caption" src="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F4.medium.gif"/></noscript></span></a></div>        <div class="figure__options">
      <ul class="highwire-figure-links"><li class="0 first"><a href="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F4.large.jpg?download=true" class="highwire-figure-link highwire-figure-link-download link-icon" title="Download Fig. 4"><i class="fa fa-download"></i> <span class="title">Download high-res image</span></a></li>
<li class="1"><a href="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F4.large.jpg" class="highwire-figure-link highwire-figure-link-newtab link-icon" target="_blank"><i class="fa fa-external-link"></i> <span class="title">Open in new tab</span></a></li>
<li class="2 last"><a href="/highwire/powerpoint/572286" class="highwire-figure-link highwire-figure-link-ppt link-icon"><i class="fa fa-download"></i> <span class="title">Download Powerpoint</span></a></li>
</ul>    </div>
      </div>
    <figcaption class="fig-caption" id="F4-caption">
    <span class="fig-label">Fig. 4</span> <span class="caption-title">Molecular evolution of the wheat lineage.</span><p id="p-35" class="first-child">SNVs were identified for coding sequences of bread wheat genes (TaAA, TaBB, and TaDD) against diploid <em>T. monococcum</em> (AA<sup>mm</sup>), <em>T. urartu</em> (AA<sup>uu</sup>), <em>Ae. speltoides</em> (SS), <em>Ae. sharonensis</em> (SshSsh), <em>Ae. tauschii</em> (DD), and tetraploid <em>T. turgidum</em> (AABB). (<strong>A</strong>) Unrooted phylogeny constructed on the basis of SNVs between bread wheat and its diploid or tetraploid relatives. The respective number of SNVs in each phylogenetic internodes is indicated with bar charts (scale at bottom left corner); colors indicate the respective bread wheat subgenome as in <a id="xref-fig-2-7" class="xref-fig" href="#F2">Fig. 2A</a>. (<strong>B</strong>) Genes with stop codons in the respective related diploid genomes in comparison to the bread wheat A, B, and D subgenomes. Numbers in node connectors or in the center correspond to the number of introduced stop codons found in two (node connectors) or all (center) related genomes. (<strong>C</strong>) Chromosomal distribution of sequence identity between bread wheat genes and the diploid and tetraploid relatives for homeologous chromosomes.</p><div class="sb-div caption-clear"></div>  </figcaption>
  </figure><p id="p-36">The potential impact of all SNVs detected on proteins was measured by using Grantham amino acid substitution matrix scores (<a id="xref-ref-25-14" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-25"><em>25</em></a>, <a id="xref-ref-61-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-61"><em>61</em></a>). Most of the substitutions (80.8%) in gene sequences were conservative or moderately conservative and were randomly distributed across all chromosomes. However, bread wheat genes contained a higher proportion of substitutions with a predicted large impact on the protein functionality (i.e., moderately radical and radical changes) compared with their closest diploid or tetraploid relatives. This points to gene redundancy in hexaploid bread wheat enabling accelerated sequence evolution and potentially the evolution of novel protein functions.</p><p id="p-37">We used the bread wheat gene annotation to analyze the introduction of likely premature stop codons in diploid and tetraploid related genomes as a measure for the rate and degree of pseudogenization (<a id="xref-fig-4-2" class="xref-fig" href="#F4">Fig. 4B</a>). Using only the highest confidence genes (HC1), 290 (1.6%; <em>T. turgidum</em> A genome versus <em>T. aestivum</em> A genome) to 636 (3.6%; <em>Ae. sharonensis</em> versus <em>T. aestivum</em> D genome) gene loci had characteristics of pseudogenization in the respective related diploid genomes compared with the respective bread wheat A, B, and D subgenomes. Most of these likely pseudogenized loci were specific to the respective genomes, although overlapping candidate pseudogenized loci were also observed. However, the numbers of genes in these categories were small, ranging from 0.1 to 0.7%. Similar inferred pseudogenization rates were found in the A and B subgenomes of <em>T. turgidum</em> [290 (1.6%) in the A genome and 395 (2.0%) in the B genome, respectively], indicating no preferential pseudogenization or gene loss in any of the subgenomes. The number of pseudogenes observed in the D genome was similar to that of the A and B subgenomes and their diploid relatives, suggesting a rapid elimination process for pseudogenes. These findings are consistent with those from other plants, notably among <em>Arabidopsis</em> ecotypes (<a id="xref-ref-62-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-62"><em>62</em></a>), and smaller-scale analysis of pseudogenization dynamics within the bread wheat genome (<a id="xref-ref-63-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-63"><em>63</em></a>).</p><p id="p-38">Earlier studies showed a high degree of gene sequence similarity between A, B, and D bread wheat subgenomes and their related diploid species (<a id="xref-ref-6-3" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-6"><em>6</em></a>). We analyzed the sequence conservation in bread wheat chromosomes compared to their diploid and tetraploid relatives to test for intergenomic translocations or introgressions (<a id="xref-fig-4-3" class="xref-fig" href="#F4">Fig. 4C</a>). The sequences of genes were highly conserved, exceeding 99% identity, between the hexaploid subgenomes and their respective diploid relatives. High levels of conservation, averaging 97%, were also found between the A, B, and D lineages.</p><p id="p-39">No gradients in sequence conservation were apparent along the chromosomes for the most closely related genomes. However, when comparing more distant genomes (e.g., <em>T. aestivum</em> D genome versus <em>T. urartu</em>), higher levels of sequence conservation were observed in genes located in proximal, pericentromeric, and centromeric regions. These results are consistent with findings for the 3B pseudomolecule analysis that demonstrated a partitioning of the chromosome with variable telomeric regions and a more conserved central chromosomal region (<a id="xref-ref-23-4" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-23"><em>23</em></a>).
