The most pronounced deviation in gene sequence similarity from the overall distribution is found for chr. 4A, which has undergone a recent inversion and translocations from chrs. 5A and 7B (<a id="xref-ref-41-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-41"><em>41</em></a>, <a id="xref-ref-42-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-42"><em>42</em></a>) (<a id="xref-fig-4-4" class="xref-fig" href="#F4">Fig. 4C</a>). Other, smaller regions showing altered similarity profiles were also observed on other chromosomes (e.g., chrs. 2A and 7B) (<a id="xref-ref-25-15" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-25"><em>25</em></a>) suggesting the presence of further small translocations or introgressions that may have occurred after hybridization.</p></div><div class="section other7" id="sec-7"><h2 class="">Hexaploid genome phylogeny</h2><p id="p-40">To further test the relatedness of the A, B, and D subgenomes across the entire wheat genome, we used syntenic gene alignments to estimate maximum likelihood phylogenetic trees. We obtained 2269 trees and analyzed them for topological variation. Across all chromosome groups, 40, 35, and 25% of the gene phylogenies supported AD, BD, and AB as the closest pairs, respectively. This genome-wide observation supports previous findings of discordant phylogenetic signals within <em>Aegilops</em> and <em>Triticum</em> genera (<a id="xref-ref-6-4" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-6"><em>6</em></a>, <a id="xref-ref-43-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-43"><em>43</em></a>, <a id="xref-ref-45-3" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-45"><em>45</em></a>). Some variation in genome relationships was found among chromosomes: On group 4 chromosomes, most gene trees supported BD as closest pairs, whereas group 5 chromosomes had similar numbers of AD and BD topologies (AD = BD &gt; AB). Distribution of variation in phylogenetic signals across homeologous chromosomes can help to better understand the nature of the evolutionary processes underlying such phylogenetic incongruence. Under incomplete lineage sorting and stochastic coalescence, levels of phylogenetic incongruence will be correlated with recombination rates, whereas single introgression events and limited recombination are expected to generate local chromosome blocks of homogenous phylogenetic signals. We used the inferred gene orders from the GenomeZipper to test for nonrandom distribution of phylogenetic signals along chromosomes. We were unable to consistently identify block structures larger than would be expected by chance. However, it is possible that the limitations of the inferred gene order hamper the ability to detect such patterns.</p></div><div class="section other8" id="sec-8"><h2 class="">Gene expression</h2><p id="p-41">Our study did not reveal any pronounced bias in gene content, structure, or composition between the different wheat subgenomes. In paleopolyploid maize and soybean, transcriptional dominance of genes derived from one progenitor genome has been described (<a id="xref-ref-64-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-64"><em>64</em></a>–<a id="xref-ref-66-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-66"><em>66</em></a>). Previous analyses have shown that rapid initiation of differential expression of homeologous wheat genes occurs upon polyploidization with a predominantly additive mode (<a id="xref-ref-13-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-13"><em>13</em></a>, <a id="xref-ref-67-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-67"><em>67</em></a>). Sets of homeologous wheat genes with only one copy present in each of the subgenomes (triads) were used to test for differential expression at a genome-wide scale. Expression correlations were calculated for 6219 triads (18,657 genes) by using RNA-seq data from five organs (leaf, root, grain, spike, and stem) (<a id="xref-fig-5-1" class="xref-fig" href="#F5">Fig. 5A</a>) (<a id="xref-ref-25-16" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-25"><em>25</em></a>). Whereas root-derived expression clustered separately, genes expressed in stem, leaves, grain, and spike clustered in a subgenome-specific manner. This indicates that the individual subgenomes exhibit a high degree of regulatory and transcriptional autonomy, with limited trans (inter-subgenome) regulation (<a id="xref-ref-68-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-68"><em>68</em></a>). At a global level, the overall pairwise expression correlation between subgenomes was very similar (<a id="xref-fig-5-2" class="xref-fig" href="#F5">Fig. 5B</a>), and no evidence for genome-wide transcriptional dominance of an individual subgenome was observed.</p><figure class="fig pos-float type-figure  odd figure figure--data" id="F5">
  <div class="figure__head highwire-figure">
    <div class="fig-inline"><a href="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F5.large.jpg?width=800&amp;height=600&amp;carousel=1" title="Subgenome transcriptional profiling for individual wheat tissues. (A) Two-dimensional hierarchical cluster analysis of single-copy wheat homeologous gene expression (colors as in Fig. 2A) compared with organ-specific gene expression. (B) Analysis of log2-fold changes in pairwise gene expression between homeologous genes (averaged across organs). Top graphs depict the distributions of log2 fold changes. Dot plots show the fold changes for each triplet ordered as shown in the y axis in (A). Colored dots highlight homologs that show significant differential expression (P &lt; 0.05). The numbers of differentially expressed triplets across all organs are shown at the bottom of the figure." class="fragment-images colorbox-load" rel="gallery-fragment-images-492649046" data-figure-caption="&lt;div class=&quot;highwire-markup&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;fig-label&quot;&gt;Fig. 5&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;caption-title&quot;&gt;Subgenome transcriptional profiling for individual wheat tissues.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;p id=&quot;p-42&quot; class=&quot;first-child&quot;&gt;(&lt;strong&gt;A&lt;/strong&gt;) Two-dimensional hierarchical cluster analysis of single-copy wheat homeologous gene expression (colors as in &lt;a id=&quot;xref-fig-2-8&quot; class=&quot;xref-fig&quot; href=&quot;#F2&quot;&gt;Fig. 2A&lt;/a&gt;) compared with organ-specific gene expression. (&lt;strong&gt;B&lt;/strong&gt;) Analysis of log&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;-fold changes in pairwise gene expression between homeologous genes (averaged across organs). Top graphs depict the distributions of log&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt; fold changes. Dot plots show the fold changes for each triplet ordered as shown in the &lt;em&gt;y&lt;/em&gt; axis in (A). Colored dots highlight homologs that show significant differential expression (&lt;em&gt;P&lt;/em&gt; &lt; 0.05). The numbers of differentially expressed triplets across all organs are shown at the bottom of the figure.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;sb-div caption-clear&quot;/&gt;&lt;/div&gt;" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0"><span class="hw-responsive-img"><img class="fragment-image lazyload" aria-describedby="F5-caption" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7" data-src="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F5.medium.gif"/><noscript><img class="fragment-image" aria-describedby="F5-caption" src="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F5.medium.gif"/></noscript></span></a></div>        <div class="figure__options">
      <ul class="highwire-figure-links"><li class="0 first"><a href="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F5.large.jpg?download=true" class="highwire-figure-link highwire-figure-link-download link-icon" title="Download Fig. 5"><i class="fa fa-download"></i> <span class="title">Download high-res image</span></a></li>
<li class="1"><a href="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F5.large.jpg" class="highwire-figure-link highwire-figure-link-newtab link-icon" target="_blank"><i class="fa fa-external-link"></i> <span class="title">Open in new tab</span></a></li>
<li class="2 last"><a href="/highwire/powerpoint/572860" class="highwire-figure-link highwire-figure-link-ppt link-icon"><i class="fa fa-download"></i> <span class="title">Download Powerpoint</span></a></li>
</ul>    </div>
      </div>
    <figcaption class="fig-caption" id="F5-caption">
    <span class="fig-label">Fig. 5</span> <span class="caption-title">Subgenome transcriptional profiling for individual wheat tissues.</span><p id="p-42" class="first-child">(<strong>A</strong>) Two-dimensional hierarchical cluster analysis of single-copy wheat homeologous gene expression (colors as in <a id="xref-fig-2-8" class="xref-fig" href="#F2">Fig. 2A</a>) compared with organ-specific gene expression. (<strong>B</strong>) Analysis of log<sub>2</sub>-fold changes in pairwise gene expression between homeologous genes (averaged across organs). Top graphs depict the distributions of log<sub>2</sub> fold changes. Dot plots show the fold changes for each triplet ordered as shown in the <em>y</em> axis in (A). Colored dots highlight homologs that show significant differential expression (<em>P</em> &lt; 0.05). The numbers of differentially expressed triplets across all organs are shown at the bottom of the figure.</p><div class="sb-div caption-clear"></div>  </figcaption>
  </figure><p id="p-43">By using hierarchical cluster analysis, we aggregated expressed genes into 13 distinct groups. These groups show predominant expression in particular organs (e.g., groups III and XIII in <a id="xref-fig-5-3" class="xref-fig" href="#F5">Fig. 5A</a>) or in one of the subgenomes (e.g., groups II, IX, and X in <a id="xref-fig-5-4" class="xref-fig" href="#F5">Fig. 5A</a>). Pairwise comparisons of individual expressed homeologous genes in the groups revealed abundant transcriptional dominance from specific subgenomes (<a id="xref-fig-5-5" class="xref-fig" href="#F5">Fig. 5B</a>). Overall, 1333 (21%) of the homeologous gene triads showed an expression bias in one of the pairwise comparisons, and we detected a similar number of preferentially transcribed genes (378 to 393) in each subgenome (permutation test; <em>P</em> &lt; 0.05). For the individual transcriptional groups, however, between 2% (groups I, IV, and V) and 20% (groups II and VI) of the genes were found to be transcriptionally dominant.</p><p id="p-44">These patterns of gene expression across the three genomes contrast with patterns of gene expression reported in allopolyploid cotton (<a id="xref-ref-69-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-69"><em>69</em></a>, <a id="xref-ref-70-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-70"><em>70</em></a>); mesopolyploid <em>Brassica rapa</em> (<a id="xref-ref-71-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-71"><em>71</em></a>); synthetic allotetraploid <em>Arabidopsis</em> (<a id="xref-ref-72-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-72"><em>72</em></a>); and the paleopolyploid maize genome (<a id="xref-ref-64-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-64"><em>64</em></a>), where one of the genomes is more transcriptionally active than others. The apparent autonomy of the three wheat subgenomes may be explained by the relatively recent polyploidization. It may also be related to regulatory mechanisms that control the transcriptional interplay of homeologous genomes to balance expression of individual and groups of genes. While maintaining subgenome-specific expression profiles, a high degree of orchestration and functional partitioning between homeologous genes was also reported in grain development of bread wheat (<a id="xref-ref-68-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-68"><em>68</em></a>) and has been attributed to the rapid evolution of cis elements coupled to epigenetic mechanisms controlling gene expression (<a id="xref-ref-68-3" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-68"><em>68</em></a>, <a id="xref-ref-73-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-73"><em>73</em></a>, <a id="xref-ref-74-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-74"><em>74</em></a>).</p></div><div class="section other9" id="sec-9"><h2 class="">Gene family size variation</h2><p id="p-45">The relationship between genes important to wheat adaptation, disease resistance, and end-use functionality in hexaploid wheat and its diploid relatives was examined for signs of adaptive evolution. These analyses identified three distinct patterns: gene expansion, gene loss, or independent gene evolution that may or may not include expansion or loss. In some cases, such as the genes containing a NB-ARC domain characteristic of many plant disease-resistance genes (<a id="xref-ref-75-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-75"><em>75</em></a>), we observed an expansion within a single subgenome (<a id="xref-fig-6-1" class="xref-fig" href="#F6">Fig. 6A</a>). Indeed, a substantial expansion in <em>Ae. tauschii</em>, compared with the other diploid species and the D genome of hexaploid wheat, is consistent with the rich reservoir of disease-resistance genes known in this species (<a id="xref-ref-17-4" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-17"><em>17</em></a>). In genes coding for the cysteine-rich gliadin domain, a functional domain characteristic of storage proteins, we observed a similar number of genes in all diploid genomes (except <em>T. monococcum</em>) that is higher than the number of genes found in each of the three hexaploid wheat subgenomes (<a id="xref-fig-6-2" class="xref-fig" href="#F6">Fig. 6B</a>). This may indicate that gene loss occurred in hexaploid wheat and that there is a trend for the gliadin gene family to maintain some homeostasis with a similar global number of genes in polyploid and diploid wheat. In other cases, the patterns observed suggested independent evolution of gene families within the different genomes and subgenomes of wheat. This was seen for genes associated with abiotic stress tolerance. For example, for genes encoding the Apetala2 (AP2) DNA binding domain, associated with drought, heat, salinity, and cold stress–tolerance responses, we observed fewer AP2 genes in the A and D genomes of Chinese Spring compared with the diploid relatives or the B subgenome (<a id="xref-fig-6-3" class="xref-fig" href="#F6">Fig. 6C</a>). Likewise, genes coding for MYB transcription factors, which have also been involved in abiotic stress response in plants (<a id="xref-ref-76-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-76"><em>76</em></a>), were underrepresented in the A subgenome of hexaploid wheat and <em>T. monococcum</em>, whereas a higher frequency was observed in <em>Ae. tauschii</em> (<a id="xref-ref-17-5" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-17"><em>17</em></a>) and <em>T. urartu</em> <em>(</em><a id="xref-ref-16-5" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-16"><em>16</em></a>) (<a id="xref-fig-6-4" class="xref-fig" href="#F6">Fig. 6D</a>).</p><figure class="fig pos-float type-figure  odd figure figure--data" id="F6">
  <div class="figure__head highwire-figure">
    <div class="fig-inline"><a href="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F6.large.jpg?width=800&amp;height=600&amp;carousel=1" title="Sizes of selected gene families and protein domains among hexaploid wheat and diploid relatives. (A) NB-ARC domain, (B) cysteine-rich gliadin domain, (C) AP2 domain, (D) MYB domain, (E) Vrn1 (MADS-box/K-box domain), and (F) Ppd (photoperiod response regulator/CCT domain)." class="fragment-images colorbox-load" rel="gallery-fragment-images-492649046" data-figure-caption="&lt;div class=&quot;highwire-markup&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;fig-label&quot;&gt;Fig. 6&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;caption-title&quot;&gt;Sizes of selected gene families and protein domains among hexaploid wheat and diploid relatives.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;p id=&quot;p-46&quot; class=&quot;first-child&quot;&gt;(&lt;strong&gt;A&lt;/strong&gt;) NB-ARC domain, (&lt;strong&gt;B&lt;/strong&gt;) cysteine-rich gliadin domain, (&lt;strong&gt;C&lt;/strong&gt;) AP2 domain, (&lt;strong&gt;D&lt;/strong&gt;) MYB domain, (&lt;strong&gt;E&lt;/strong&gt;) &lt;em&gt;Vrn1&lt;/em&gt; (MADS-box/K-box domain), and (&lt;strong&gt;F&lt;/strong&gt;) &lt;em&gt;Ppd&lt;/em&gt; (photoperiod response regulator/CCT domain).&lt;/p&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;sb-div caption-clear&quot;/&gt;&lt;/div&gt;" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0"><span class="hw-responsive-img"><img class="fragment-image lazyload" aria-describedby="F6-caption" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7" data-src="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F6.medium.gif"/><noscript><img class="fragment-image" aria-describedby="F6-caption" src="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F6.medium.gif"/></noscript></span></a></div>        <div class="figure__options">
      <ul class="highwire-figure-links"><li class="0 first"><a href="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F6.large.jpg?download=true" class="highwire-figure-link highwire-figure-link-download link-icon" title="Download Fig. 6"><i class="fa fa-download"></i> <span class="title">Download high-res image</span></a></li>
<li class="1"><a href="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/sci/345/6194/1251788/F6.large.jpg" class="highwire-figure-link highwire-figure-link-newtab link-icon" target="_blank"><i class="fa fa-external-link"></i> <span class="title">Open in new tab</span></a></li>
<li class="2 last"><a href="/highwire/powerpoint/572257" class="highwire-figure-link highwire-figure-link-ppt link-icon"><i class="fa fa-download"></i> <span class="title">Download Powerpoint</span></a></li>
</ul>    </div>
      </div>
    <figcaption class="fig-caption" id="F6-caption">
    <span class="fig-label">Fig. 6</span> <span class="caption-title">Sizes of selected gene families and protein domains among hexaploid wheat and diploid relatives.</span><p id="p-46" class="first-child">(<strong>A</strong>) NB-ARC domain, (<strong>B</strong>) cysteine-rich gliadin domain, (<strong>C</strong>) AP2 domain, (<strong>D</strong>) MYB domain, (<strong>E</strong>) <em>Vrn1</em> (MADS-box/K-box domain), and (<strong>F</strong>) <em>Ppd</em> (photoperiod response regulator/CCT domain).</p><div class="sb-div caption-clear"></div>  </figcaption>
  </figure><p id="p-47">In contrast, there was no evidence of expansion or loss of genes underlying phenology, such as the vernalization (<em>Vrn1</em>) and photoperiod response regulator (<em>Ppd1</em>) genes that differentiate spring and winter growth habits and sensitivity to day length, respectively. Similar numbers of genes were found in the diploids and hexaploid subgenomes coding for the two functional domains of <em>Vrn1</em>, a MADS-box and K-box domain (<a id="xref-ref-77-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-77"><em>77</em></a>) (<a id="xref-fig-6-5" class="xref-fig" href="#F6">Fig. 6E</a>), and for genes containing the response regulator domain and CCT motif typical of cereal <em>Ppd</em> genes (<a id="xref-ref-78-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-78"><em>78</em></a>) (<a id="xref-fig-6-6" class="xref-fig" href="#F6">Fig. 6F</a>). We identified an additional copy of a <em>Vrn1</em>-like gene in the hexaploid Chinese Spring A and D genomes and <em>T. urartu</em> (<a id="xref-ref-16-6" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-16"><em>16</em></a>) when compared with the remaining diploid species. An additional copy of a <em>Ppd1</em>-like gene was also identified in the Chinese Spring B genome relative to <em>Ae. sharonesis</em> and <em>Ae. speltoides</em> (<a id="xref-fig-6-7" class="xref-fig" href="#F6">Fig. 6F</a>). Although only small differences were observed, small increases in copy number variation of <em>Vrn-A1</em> (A genome) and <em>Ppd-B1</em> (B genome) have been associated with longer periods of vernalization to potentiate flowering and an early flowering day neutral phenotype, respectively (<a id="xref-ref-79-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-79"><em>79</em></a>). Thus, the relative distribution of such patterns in ontology of these two genes is likely to reflect important factors that have allowed wheat to adjust its flowering time to adapt to a range of environmental conditions.</p></div><div class="section other10" id="sec-10"><h2 class="">Molecular markers</h2><p id="p-48">Wheat improvement relies in part on the use of molecular markers to improve selection efficiencies and to allow the precise transfer of genes and QTL between different genetic backgrounds. To enhance the CSS as a genomic resource for the wheat genetics and breeding community, we anchored all publicly available DNA markers that are routinely used for genetic mapping and marker-assisted breeding in wheat. Because the majority of these markers are anchored to phenotypic maps, anchoring them to the CSS allows immediate association of CSS to traits targeted by breeders. In addition, insertion site–based polymorphism (ISBP) and SNP markers identified from recent whole-genome shotgun and transcriptome sequencing (<a id="xref-ref-19-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-19"><em>19</em></a>) and genotyping by sequencing (GBS) tags identified by using DArTSeq (Diversity Arrays Technology, Bruce, Australia) technology were also anchored. In total, over 3.6 million marker loci were anchored to the CSS, including 1,347,669 marker loci and 2,310,988 SNPs (<a id="xref-table-wrap-5-1" class="xref-table" href="#T5">Table 5</a>).</p><div id="T5" class="table pos-float"><div class="table-caption"><span class="table-label">Table 5</span> <span class="caption-title">Number and type of molecular markers mapped on individual chromosomes of the bread wheat genome.</span><p id="p-49" class="first-child"> </p><div class="sb-div caption-clear"></div></div><div class="table-inline"><div class="callout"><span>View this table:</span><ul class="callout-links"><li><a href="/highwire/markup/572279/expansion?width=1000&amp;height=500&amp;iframe=true&amp;postprocessors=highwire_figures%2Chighwire_math%2Chighwire_embed" class="colorbox colorbox-load table-expand-popup" rel="gallery-fragment-tables" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0">View popup</a></li><li><a href="" class="table-expand-inline" data-table-url="/highwire/markup/572279/expansion?postprocessors=highwire_figures%2Chighwire_math%2Chighwire_embed" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0">View inline</a></li></ul></div></div></div><p id="p-50">Most marker types showed a distribution gradient across subgenomes, with the highest number associated with the B genome chromosomes and the lowest with the D genome, reflecting the differences in the level of polymorphism in these subgenomes. The proportions of ISBPs, SNPs detected from cultivar sequencing and GBS tags localized to the D genome ranged between 9.3 and 12%, with the lowest numbers mapping to the group 4 chromosomes (<a id="xref-table-wrap-5-2" class="xref-table" href="#T5">Table 5</a>). Two hundred and ninety-two of 1867 simple sequence repeat (SSR) loci were successfully anchored to the CSS survey sequence. This low number is not surprising, given that these loci derive from repetitive AT- and GC-rich sequences that may be collapsed or represented by uneven read coverage in Illumina sequences (<a id="xref-ref-80-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-80"><em>80</em></a>).</p><p id="p-51">Well over 70 DNA markers are routinely deployed by breeders for agronomic, pest resistance, and end-use quality, and most are available in the public domain (<a href="http://maswheat.ucdavis.edu">http://maswheat.ucdavis.edu</a>). Anchoring of these to the CSS would facilitate identification of SNP markers for development of high-density marker maps, as a resource of correlated markers, and to aid map-based cloning of genes underlying important traits. In total, we anchored 68 of these markers to 74 contigs in the CSS. The application of the CSS in marker improvement was demonstrated with the CAPS (cleaved amplified polymorphic sequence) marker <em>Usw47</em>, which is linked to <em>Cdu-B1</em>, a gene responsible for reduced grain cadmium content in tetraploid wheat (<a id="xref-ref-81-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-81"><em>81</em></a>, <a id="xref-ref-82-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-82"><em>82</em></a>). Although <em>Usw47</em> is routinely used in marker-assisted selection, it is not amenable to high-throughput genotyping. Alignment of the <em>Usw47</em> sequence against the CSS mapped it to contig 5BL-10759151. This and eight neighboring contigs in the GenomeZipper contained 33 SNP markers, of which 5 were polymorphic in a doubled haploid mapping population used previously to localize <em>Cdu-B1</em>. Of the five SNP markers, two co-segregated, and the remainder flanked the gene by a single recombination event. These SNP markers can be readily implemented now in a high-throughput fashion to select for reduced grain cadmium content within breeding programs.</p></div><div class="section conclusions" id="sec-11"><h2 class="">Conclusion</h2><p id="p-52">We present the ordered and structured draft sequence of the bread wheat genome as well as a comparison between eight related wheat genomes. We defined a gene catalog for each of the 21 bread wheat chromosomes and positioned more than 75,000 genes along the chromosomes by using a combination of high-density wheat SNP mapping and synteny to sequenced grass genomes. In contrast to other species (<a id="xref-ref-83-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-83"><em>83</em></a>), polyploidization events in wheat did not cause a “genome shock” with subsequent rapid genome changes or functional dominance of one subgenome over the others. Intraspecific comparative analyses revealed a dynamic wheat genome with a high level of plasticity and a changing gene repertoire shaped by gene losses and gene-family expansions in all wheat genomes and subgenomes, with only a few species-specific genes. Through interspecific comparisons, we observed a higher abundance of intrachromosomal gene duplications in wheat compared with other grass genomes, which may be a mechanism for functional adaptation and underlie the global success of wheat as a cultivated crop.</p><p id="p-53">The detection, chromosomal assignment, and description of a large proportion of the gene complement of bread wheat and their positional assignment on chromosome arms is a major milestone in facilitating the isolation of genes underlying agronomically important traits, providing a reference for future integration into systems biology, and improving wheat breeding efficiency. Already, the resources developed in this work have been used to support the analysis of selected wheat chromosomes (<a id="xref-ref-20-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-20"><em>20</em></a>, <a id="xref-ref-41-3" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-41"><em>41</em></a>, <a id="xref-ref-84-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-84"><em>84</em></a>–<a id="xref-ref-86-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-86"><em>86</em></a>). Last, as demonstrated by the completion of the reference sequence for chr. 3B (<a id="xref-ref-23-5" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-23"><em>23</em></a>), this draft genome sequence and complementary resources will support the assembly and annotation of the physical map–based reference sequences for the 21 bread wheat chromosomes.</p><p id="p-54"><strong>Correction (22 September 2014):</strong> The last row of Table 3 has been updated.</p></div><div class="section app" id="app-1"><h2 class="">Supplementary Materials</h2><div id="DC1" class="supplementary-material"><p id="p-55"><a href="http://www.sciencemag.org/content/345/6194/1251788/suppl/DC1">www.sciencemag.org/content/345/6194/1251788/suppl/DC1</a></p><p id="p-56">Materials and Methods</p><p id="p-57">Supplementary Text</p><p id="p-58">Figs. S1 to S60</p><p id="p-59">Tables S1 to S48</p><p id="p-60">References (<a id="xref-ref-88-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-88"><em>88</em></a>–<a id="xref-ref-160-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-160"><em>160</em></a>)</p></div></div><div class="section app" id="app-2"><h2 class="">The International Wheat Genome Sequencing Consortium (IWGSC)</h2><p id="p-61">Authorship of this paper should be cited as “International Wheat Genome Sequencing Consortium.” Participants are arranged by working group. Text</p><p id="p-121">Figs. S.</span> <span class="cit-name-surname">Harris</span></span>, </li><li><span class="cit-auth"> <span class="cit-name-given-names">G. J.</span> <span class="cit-name-surname">Taylor</span></span></li></ol><cite>, 
<span class="cit-article-title">Cadmium uptake and partitioning in durum wheat during grain filling</span>. <abbr class="cit-jnl-abbrev">BMC Plant Biol.</abbr> 
<span class="cit-vol">13</span>, 
<span class="cit-fpage">103</span> (<span class="cit-pub-date">2013</span>).<span class="cit-pub-id-sep cit-pub-id-doi-sep"> </span><span class="cit-pub-id cit-pub-id-doi"><span class="cit-pub-id-scheme-doi">doi:</span>10.1186/1471-2229-13-103</span><span class="cit-pub-id-sep cit-pub-id-pmid-sep"> </span><span class="cit-pub-id cit-pub-id-pmid"><span class="cit-pub-id-scheme-pmid">pmid:</span>23856013</span></cite></div><div class="cit-extra"><a href="{openurl}?query=rft.jtitle%253DBMC%2BPlant%2BBiol.%26rft.volume%253D13%26rft.spage%253D103%26rft_id%253Dinfo%253Adoi%252F10.1186%252F1471-2229-13-103%26rft_id%253Dinfo%253Apmid%252F23856013%26rft.genre%253Darticle%26rft_val_fmt%253Dinfo%253Aofi%252Ffmt%253Akev%253Amtx%253Ajournal%26ctx_ver%253DZ39.88-2004%26url_ver%253DZ39.88-2004%26url_ctx_fmt%253Dinfo%253Aofi%252Ffmt%253Akev%253Amtx%253Actx" class="cit-ref-sprinkles cit-ref-sprinkles-openurl cit-ref-sprinkles-open-url"><span>OpenUrl</span></a><a href="/lookup/external-ref?access_num=10.1186/1471-2229-13-103&amp;link_type=DOI" class="cit-ref-sprinkles cit-ref-sprinkles-doi cit-ref-sprinkles-crossref"><span>CrossRef</span></a><a href="/lookup/external-ref?access_num=23856013&amp;link_type=MED&amp;atom=%2Fsci%2F345%2F6194%2F1251788.atom" class="cit-ref-sprinkles cit-ref-sprinkles-medline"><span>PubMed</span></a></div></div></li><li><div class="cit ref-cit ack no-rev-xref"><strong>Acknowledgments: </strong>The authors would like to thank Graminor AS; Biogemma; Institut National de la Recherche Agronomique (INRA); International Center for Agricultural Research in the Dry Areas; Department of Biotechnology, Ministry of Science and Technology, Government of India (chr. 2A; grant no. BT/IWGSC/03/TF/2008); and the Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council (BBSRC UK) for funding the chromosome sequencing at the Genome Analysis Centre. Chromosome sequencing at other centers was funded by the following: chr. 3A—U.S. Department of Agriculture Agriculture and Food Research Initiative (USDA AFRI) Triticeae-CAP (2011-68002-30029) and the Kansas Wheat Commission; chr. 3B—grants from the French National Research Agency (ANR-09- GENM-025 3BSEQ) and France Agrimer; chr. 6B—grants from the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries of Japan “Genomics for agricultural innovation KGS-1003,1004”, “Genomics based technology for agricultural improvement, NGB- 1003,” and Nisshin Flour Milling Incorporated; chr. 6D and <em>Triticum durum</em> cv. Strongfield—grants from Genome Canada, Genome Prairie, University of Saskatchewan Ministry of Agriculture, Western Grains Research Foundation; chr. 7B—grant no. 199387 from the Norwegian Research Council and from Graminor AS; chr. 7A and 7D sequence reads were provided by D.E.. Chromosome flow sorting and DNA preparation was supported through grants P501/12/G090 and P501/12/2554 from the Czech Science foundation. Chromosome sequence assembly was supported by the BBSRC (UK). K.F.X.M. acknowledges grants from the German Ministry for Education and Research (BMBF) Plant2030, TRITEX, Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (DFG) SFB 924, and EC Transplant. K.E. and J.R. are supported by sponsors of the IWGSC, which include Arcadia Biosciences, Australian Centre for Plant Functional Genomics, Biogemma, Bayer CropScience, Commonwealth Science and Industrial Research Organisation, Centro Internacional de Mejoramiento de Maíz y Trigo, Céréales Vallée, Dow AgroSciences, Dupont, Evogene, Florimond Desprez, Grains Research and Development Corporation, Graminor, Heartland Plant Innovation, INRA, KWS, Kansas Wheat Commission, Limagrain, Monsanto, RAGT, and Syngenta. N.G. is supported by European Commission Marie Curie Actions (FP7-MC-IIF-Noncollinear Genes). T.W. is supported by the Swiss National Foundation and P.F., M.C., A.M.S., and L.C. are supported by the Italian Ministry of Agriculture special project “MAPPA-5A.” H.B. acknowledges funding from Sabanci University and the Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey. B.W. and B.S. were funded by the Gatsby Charitable Foundation and the BBSRC (UK) Grant BB/J003166/1. R.W. is a Trustee Director of TGAC, Norwich, UK, and A.K. is a shareholder of Diversity Arrays Technology Pty Ltd. The POPSeq analysis carried out by the U.S. Department of Energy Joint Genome Institute was supported by the Office of Science of the U.S. Department of Energy under contract no. DE-AC02-05CH11231. Additional support for the work was funded from the Triticeae-CAP, USDA AFRI (2011-68002-30029) to G.J.M.; the Scottish Government Rural and Environment Science and Analytical Services Division Research Programme to R.W.; and the German Ministry of Research and Education (BMBF TRITEX 0315954) to N.S. Sequence reads and assembled sequences are available at European Molecular Biology Laboratory/GenBank/DNA Data Bank of Japan short read archives and sequence repositories, respectively (PRJEB3955—whole-genome sequences of <em>T. aestivum</em> ‘Chinese Spring,’ <em>T. urartu</em>, <em>Ae. speltoides</em>, <em>Ae. tauschii</em>, <em>T. turgidum</em>; SRP004490.3—whole-genome sequencing of <em>T. monococcum</em>; SRP004490—whole-genome sequencing of <em>Ae. tauschii</em>; PRJEB4849—whole-genome sequences of <em>Ae. sharonensis</em>; PRJEB4750—<em>T. aestivum</em> RNA-seq data; SRP037990—<em>T. aestivum</em> SynOpDH mapping population; SRP037781—<em>T. aestivum</em> synthetic opata M85; SRP037994—<em>T. aestivum</em> synthetic W7984). All data can be accessed via the IWGSC repository at Unité de Rercherche Génomique Info: <a href="http://wheat-urgi.versailles.inra.fr/Seq-Repository/">http://wheat-urgi.versailles.inra.fr/Seq-Repository/</a>.<div class="cit-extra"></div></div></li></ol></div><span class="highwire-journal-article-marker-end"></span></div><span id="related-urls"></span></div><a href="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/345/6194/1251788.abstract" class="hw-link hw-link-article-abstract" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0">View Abstract</a></div>  </div>

            <h3 class="overline">
          Navigate This Article        </h3>

class="highwire-article-nav-jumplink" data-panel-ajax-tab="jnl_sci_tab_art" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0">miRNAs</a></li><li class="odd"><a href="#sec-4" class="highwire-article-nav-jumplink" data-panel-ajax-tab="jnl_sci_tab_art" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0">Protein-coding genes</a></li><li class="even"><a href="#sec-5" class="highwire-article-nav-jumplink" data-panel-ajax-tab="jnl_sci_tab_art" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0">Gene distribution and order</a></li><li class="odd"><a href="#sec-6" class="highwire-article-nav-jumplink" data-panel-ajax-tab="jnl_sci_tab_art" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0">Comparisons with related species</a></li><li class="even"><a href="#sec-7" class="highwire-article-nav-jumplink" data-panel-ajax-tab="jnl_sci_tab_art" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0">Hexaploid genome phylogeny</a></li><li class="odd"><a href="#sec-8" class="highwire-article-nav-jumplink" data-panel-ajax-tab="jnl_sci_tab_art" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0">Gene expression</a></li><li class="even"><a href="#sec-9" class="highwire-article-nav-jumplink" data-panel-ajax-tab="jnl_sci_tab_art" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0">Gene family size variation</a></li><li class="odd"><a href="#sec-10" class="highwire-article-nav-jumplink" data-panel-ajax-tab="jnl_sci_tab_art" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0">Molecular markers</a></li><li class="even"><a href="#sec-11" class="highwire-article-nav-jumplink" data-panel-ajax-tab="jnl_sci_tab_art" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0">Conclusion</a></li><li class="odd"><a href="#app-1" class="highwire-article-nav-jumplink" data-panel-ajax-tab="jnl_sci_tab_art" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0">Supplementary Materials</a></li><li class="even"><a href="#app-2" class="highwire-article-nav-jumplink" data-panel-ajax-tab="jnl_sci_tab_art" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0">The International Wheat Genome Sequencing Consortium (IWGSC)</a></li><li class="last odd"><a href="#ref-list-1" class="highwire-article-nav-jumplink last" data-panel-ajax-tab="jnl_sci_tab_art" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0">References and Notes</a></li></ul></li><li class="even"><a href="/content/345/6194/1251788/tab-figures-data" class="highwire-article-nav-jumplink" data-panel-ajax-tab="jnl_sci_tab_data" data-is-tab-link="true" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0">Figures & Data</a></li><li class="odd"><a href="/content/345/6194/1251788/tab-article-info" class="highwire-article-nav-jumplink" data-panel-ajax-tab="jnl_sci_tab_info" data-is-tab-link="true" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0">Info & Metrics</a></li><li class="even"><a href="/content/345/6194/1251788/tab-e-letters" class="highwire-article-nav-jumplink" data-panel-ajax-tab="article_tab_eletters" data-is-tab-link="true" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0">eLetters</a></li><li class="last odd"><a href="/content/345/6194/1251788/tab-pdf" class="highwire-article-nav-jumplink" data-panel-ajax-tab="jnl_sci_tab_pdf" data-is-tab-link="true" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0"><i class="fa fa-file-pdf-o"></i> PDF</a></li></ul></div>  
</div>
    </div>
      </div>
</div></div>  </div>
  </div>
<div class="row row--alt row--promo">
    <div  class="region region-pre-footer pre--footer container--promo container">
    
  <div class="primary"><h2 class="subsection-title heading--block"><a href="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/current" target="_blank">Read the Latest Issue of <em>Science</em></a></h2>
  <div class="primary__main promo-foot--mag"><div class="promo-foot--current">
  
        
      <div class="highwire-article-citation highwire-citation-type-highwire-issue" data-pisa="sci;371/6526" data-pisa-master="sci;371/6526" data-apath="/sci/371/6526.atom" id="sci3716526atom"><h3>15 January 2021</h3>
<p class="promo-foot__meta">Vol 371, Issue 6526</p>
<a href="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/current" target="_blank" class="" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0"><img class="promo-foot__cover" src="https://science.sciencemag.org/sites/default/files/styles/sci_footer_promo_cover/public/externals/14067c1c7f0ec4e8744a44035d73cebe.gif?itok=6HXLnRKP" alt="Magazine Cover" /></a></div><p><a href="http://science.sciencemag.org/content/371/6526" class="btn--cta btn--cta--small" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0">Table of Contents</a></p>  
</div>
<div class="promo-foot--heds">
  
        
      <ul class="media-grid media-grid--2 media-grid--minor"><li class="first"><div class="highwire-article-citation highwire-citation-type-highwire-article" data-pisa="sci;371/6526/225" data-pisa-master="sci;371/6526/225" data-apath="/sci/371/6526/225.atom" id="sci3716526225atom"><h3 class="overline">Feature</h3>
  <a href="/content/371/6526/225" class="highwire-cite-linked-title" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0"><span class="highwire-cite-title">Fallen giant</span></a></div></li>
<li><div class="highwire-article-citation highwire-citation-type-highwire-article" data-pisa="sci;371/6526/239" data-pisa-master="sci;371/6526/239" data-apath="/sci/371/6526/239.atom" id="sci3716526239atom"><h3 class="overline">Biodiversity</h3>
  <a href="/content/371/6526/239" class="highwire-cite-linked-title" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0"><span class="highwire-cite-title">Tracking, targeting, and conserving soil biodiversity</span></a></div></li>
<li><div class="highwire-article-citation highwire-citation-type-highwire-article" data-pisa="sci;371/6526/242" data-pisa-master="sci;371/6526/242" data-apath="/sci/371/6526/242.atom" id="sci3716526242atom"><h3 class="overline">Climate Science</h3>
  <a href="/content/371/6526/242" class="highwire-cite-linked-title" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0"><span class="highwire-cite-title">Fighting the good fight</span></a></div></li>
<li><div class="highwire-article-citation highwire-citation-type-highwire-article" data-pisa="sci;371/6526/216" data-pisa-master="sci;371/6526/216" data-apath="/sci/371/6526/216.atom" id="sci3716526216atom"><h3 class="overline">SCI COMMUN</h3>
  <a href="/content/371/6526/216" class="highwire-cite-linked-title" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0"><span class="highwire-cite-title">News at a glance</span></a></div></li>
<li><div class="highwire-article-citation highwire-citation-type-highwire-article" data-pisa="sci;371/6526/230" data-pisa-master="sci;371/6526/230" data-apath="/sci/371/6526/230.atom" id="sci3716526230atom"><h3 class="overline">Coronavirus</h3>
  <a href="/content/371/6526/230" class="highwire-cite-linked-title" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0"><span class="highwire-cite-title">Herd immunity by infection is not an option</span></a></div></li>
<li class="last"><div class="highwire-article-citation highwire-citation-type-highwire-article" data-pisa="sci;371/6526/314" data-pisa-master="sci;371/6526/314" data-apath="/sci/371/6526/314.atom" id="sci3716526314atom"><h3 class="overline">Working Life</h3>
  <a href="/content/371/6526/314" class="highwire-cite-linked-title" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0"><span class="highwire-cite-title">No use in shouting</span></a></div></li>
</ul>
